headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and thank you for holding. Today’s call is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. The presentation material and additional financial tables are currently posted on Motorola Mobility’s Investor Relati
componenttext:
Good afternoon and thank you for holding. Today’s call is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. The presentation material and additional financial tables are currently posted on Motorola Mobility’s Investor Relations website. A replay of this call will be available approximately three hours after the conclusion of this call. Our Investor Relations website is at http://investors.motorola.com.
At this time, all participants have been placed in a listen-only mode and the floor will be open your questions following the presentation.
I would now like to introduce Mr. Dean Lindroth, Corporate Vice President and Investor Relations Officer. Mr. Lindroth, you may begin your conference.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to Motorola Mobility’s First Quarter Results Conference Call. Today’s call will include prepared remarks by Sanjay Jha, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; and Marc Rothman, Chief Financial Officer. Dan Moloney,
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon. Welcome to Motorola Mobility’s First Quarter Results Conference Call. Today’s call will include prepared remarks by Sanjay Jha, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman; and Marc Rothman, Chief Financial Officer. Dan Moloney, President of Motorola Mobility will join for the Q&A portion of the call.
Today’s presentation includes a number of forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are any statements that are not historical facts. These forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations and there can be no assurance that such expectations will be achieved.
Because forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties, actual results could differ materially from these statements. Information about factors that could cause and in some cases have caused such differences can be found in today’s press release, our 2010 10-K and our other SEC filings. The content of this presentation contains time-sensitive information. We’ll not be reviewing or updating this material should it be retransmitted or redistributed at a later date.
I’ll now turn the call over to Sanjay.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dean. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us today. I will begin today with a review of the business. Marc will then discuss the detailed financial results and our guidance, after that we’ll take your question.In January, Mobile Device
componenttext:
Thank you, Dean. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us today. I will begin today with a review of the business. Marc will then discuss the detailed financial results and our guidance, after that we’ll take your question.
In January, Mobile Devices and Home became an independent public company, particularly well-positioned for the opportunities in smartphones, tablets, video solutions and converged experiences.
During the first quarter, we grew our business and diversified our sales mix. We launched two new smartphones, bringing our total cumulative smartphone launches to 27 and total smartphone shipments to nearly 20 million units.
We shipped the first tablet running Android 3.0. We introduced ATRIX, WebTop and Lapdock, an innovative mobile computing experience for consumers and the enterprise. And we addressed our supply chain challenges created by the tragic events in Japan.
We accomplished a lot, but we also have some takeaway. We know that consumers want to expand their price points and enhanced productivity suite functionalities for the ATRIX Lapdock bundle. Consumers want more apps for Android tablets and with the delay of Bionic from the second quarter to this summer we know that execution needs to get better.
From a financial results’ perspective, we grew our revenue to $3 billion - to $3 billion, a growth of 22% year-over-year.
On a non-GAAP basis, the net loss was $0.08 per share, an 83% improvement, compared to a loss of $0.48 per share in the year ago quarter. We exceeded the top-end of our guidance range with strong results in our Home businesses - Home business and by reducing our year-over-year operating loss in Mobile Devices.
From a cash perspective, we generated $107 million in operating cash flow. In Mobile Devices business, we shipped 4.1 million smartphones and over 250,000 tablets.
Our revenue mix was more diversified in the quarter and reflected our effort to drive growth in geographies outside of North America. In the quarter, China and Latin America and other international markets accounted for 44% of total Mobile Devices revenue, compared to 37% in the fourth quarter of 2010 and 34% in the year-ago quarter.
This increase was driven primarily by smartphone shipments outside of North America that were more than twice the level of the year ago quarter, accounting for over 50% of our smartphone unit shipment.
This compares to one-third of smartphone shipments in the fourth quarter of last year and 25% in the year ago quarter. In China, we increased our presence across the retail channel, strengthened our carrier sales efforts, enhanced point of sale branding and expanded our smartphone portfolio.
From a product perspective, with more than 20 smartphones to launch since the end of 2009 in China, we continue to be a leading provider of Android smartphones. DEFY, our life proof water resistant smartphone, with the dual-mode, dual-standby XT800 were two of the best selling smartphones in China.
In the quarter, smartphone shipments exceeded 1 million units or more than half of what we shipped all of last year. In the second quarter, we will begin to ship ATRIX and two new dual-core smartphones developed specifically for the China market. These include the dual SIM XT882 for China Telecom and MT870 for China Mobile.
In Latin America, market demand continues to be very strong. In the quarter, we expanded our retail presence in key markets. We also introduced DEFY with both SIM and bebo in Brazil and Telecom Personal and Claro in Argentina.
Smartphone shipments were up year-over-year and sequentially with SPICE and DEFY our top sellers. In the second quarter, we are adding ATRIX to our Latin American line up, beginning with this month’s launch in Brazil.
In Europe, smartphone shipments grew compared to the year ago quarter. We’re getting good traction in our portfolio with DEFY being our leading seller and we’re beginning to increase our media presence as part of our plan to further grow our sales.
In North America, we launched our first high-performance smartphone with AT&T, the ATRIX 4G, when combined with its companion Lapdock and enabled by our WebTop application, ATRIX delivers a new experience in mobile computing. Total smartphone shipments in the quarter, including solid sales of the Droid family of devices increased by over 10%, compared to the year ago quarter.
In tablets, we have an incremental growth opportunity in we - in which we can leverage existing investments in R&D and distribution. In February, we launched the Motorola XOOM, the first tablet on Android 3.0 with Verizon. In March, we introduced the XOOM Wi-Fi only tablet at seven major U.S. retailers, including Amazon, Best Buy, Costco and Staples.
We also re-entered the Japan market by launching the Wi-Fi tablet with KDDI. In the quarter, we shipped over 250,000 tablets. We plan to further expand our - expand availability by launching our Wi-Fi tablet at Sprint and internationally we will begin shipping this quarter in China, Brazil, Argentina, Korea and Germany.
In the second quarter, we have the opportunity to significantly increase second quarter XOOM shipments compared to the first quarter. Our LTE upgrade to XOOM will be available in summer, followed by additional 4G and Wi-Fi tablets, including new form factors later this year.
As we look ahead within the Android ecosystem, we have a very strong pipeline of devices and experiences. We plan to differentiate ourselves in the following four key areas.
In mobile computing, we created a whole new experience category with the introduction of Motorola ATRIX 4G, Lapdock and our proprietary WebTop software. This unique product offering simplifies, improve and dramatically reduces the cost of existing mobile computing solutions for consumers, as well as business users.
In May, the full bundle of Motorola ATRIX 4G smartphone, WebTop software and Lapdock will be offered at AT&T for $399 after mail in rebate. We also plan on introducing successive iterations of our WebTop software and related accessories that incorporate improved productivity tools at multiple price point.
Second, in the enterprise, our focus is on differentiated software to optimize Android for business. Devices including DROID Pro, ATRIX and XOOM have demonstrated a strong value proposition and helped accelerate the level of interest in adoption of Android-based devices in the enterprise.
Technology from our wholly owned subsidiary 3LM enables superior device level security and manageability specifically for Android devices. We are also working with a number of other enterprise software partners to deliver fully integrated solutions for the enterprise.
Third, in media and content services, the user-based on MOTOBLUR, a cloud-based services platform continues to grow and it’s currently over 7 million users. We intend to continue to evolve the platform to support enhanced services and improve the device management. We also plan on utilizing Zecter’s innovative applications and services technology so that users of our smartphones and tablets will have access to their content anywhere, anytime.
Finally, we’re continuing to work on converged Home experiences that provide our customers with infrastructure-based solutions that blend video and entertainment delivery with Internet communication. In addition, we’re developing consumer centric devices for interactive multi-screen features and services.
Turning now to Home. In the Home business, compared to a year ago, revenues were up and operating margin was higher. This team is delivering solid financial results, holding share in priority markets, introducing new products and services and taking the lead in critical industry transitions, such as multi-screen content delivery and all-IP video.
In this business, we are prioritizing our R&D investments to ensure sustainable profitability in our core business and to position us for growth in new market segments such as software services and media experiences.
For the near-term we continue to invest in our consumer premise equipment portfolio, our network infrastructure and on our software and services offering to further enhance our solutions for end operators.
For a longer-term perspective, we are investing in the transformation to all IP network and cloud-based multi-screen consumer experiences. For operators, this means developing next-generation infrastructure and software solutions to provide more bandwidth capacity, IP-based content distribution, cloud-based service management and processing and delivery of content to multiple screens.
For consumers, this means creating IP-based Home network and devices that enable a connected ecosystem which provides a broad range of video experiences, including multi-room DVRs, streaming TV and sync and go content mobility. To support these efforts, we have acquired several software-based companies, including 4Home, Zecter, and, most recently, Dreampark, a leading provider of software solutions for IPTV systems.
With Dreampark's portfolio, we can further enhance the capabilities of operators to customize their consumer-facing service portal regardless of the screen being used. Together, the software technologies we have acquired and those developed internally have been integrated into a comprehensive software portfolio.
The result is an increasing number of solutions which help drive incremental revenue and increased differentiation for network operators. With that, I will now turn the call over to Marc to provide additional details on the financial results for the quarter and our guidance. Marc?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sanjay. Motorola Mobility revenues were $3 billion in the first quarter, up 22% from the first quarter of 2010. On a GAAP basis, we reported an operating loss of $36 million. Non-GAAP adjustments totaled an expense of $56 million and related to
componenttext:
Thank you, Sanjay. Motorola Mobility revenues were $3 billion in the first quarter, up 22% from the first quarter of 2010. On a GAAP basis, we reported an operating loss of $36 million. Non-GAAP adjustments totaled an expense of $56 million and related to stock compensation expense and intangible asset amortization.
On a non-GAAP basis, operating earnings were $20 million. This was favorable to our operating earnings guidance and a significant improvement compared to the operating loss of $101 million in the year-ago quarter.
We reported a first quarter GAAP loss per share of $0.27, compared to a loss of $0.72 per share in the year ago quarter. On a non-GAAP basis, the first quarter loss was $0.08 per share, compared to a loss of $0.48 per share in the first quarter of 2010. Earnings per share exceeded the top end of our guidance of a loss of $0.09 to $0.21 per share, reflecting a strong quarter in the home business and in-line results for mobile devices.
Further details on our non-GAAP results are included as part of today's press release and available on our website. My remaining income statement references will be on a non-GAAP basis.
The first quarter gross margin percentage of Motorola Mobility was 25.0%, compared to 24.3% in the first quarter of 2010. The improvement was driven by higher gross margin levels in both mobile devices and home.
On a sequential basis, gross margin percentage was lower, due largely to product mix and international growth, resulting in mid-range smartphones representing a larger percentage of the overall portfolio mix. The operating expenses in the quarter were $739 million, up 5% year-over-year.
This increase is attributable largely to higher sales and marketing expenses to support business growth in mobile devices. Head count in the company was essentially unchanged from year-end.
Total non-operating expenses were $15 million, reflecting foreign-exchange costs as well as certain non-recurring costs related to our separation. The provision for income taxes was $30 million, slightly higher than our forecast, attributable to changes in our geographic mix of operating income and losses.
Turning now to our business segments, in mobile devices, first-quarter revenues were $2.1 million, up 30% year-over-year. Total mobile device shipments were $9.3 million units, including 4.1 million smartphones and over 250,000 XOOM tablets.
Our overall ASP increased to $229, compared to $214 in the fourth quarter of last year. This increase was driven by tablets. The non-GAAP operating loss in mobile devices was $61 million, compared to a loss of $148 million in the first quarter of 2010.
The year-over-year improvement was driven by higher smartphone sales and improved gross margin percentage, offset partially by higher advertising and promotion expenses in key markets around the world.
Turning to the home business. In the home business, first-quarter revenues were $904 million, up 8% year-over-year. This reflects higher set-top box revenues and a comparable level of infrastructure sales.
With respect to the growth rate, recall that during the first and second quarters of 2010, the industry was experiencing a reduced level of demand, particularly in the U.S. Demand levels began to recover in the second half of last year and as a result, year-on-year growth rates in the first half of this year are expected to be higher than what we anticipate for the second half of 2011.
Non-GAAP operating margin was 9%, compared to 5.6% in the first quarter of last year. The margin in the quarter reflects leverage on the revenue growth, a favorable product mix and controls over operating expenses.
Moving now to cash flow and the balance sheet. From a cash perspective, we generated $107 million of cash, our seventh consecutive quarter of positive operating cash flow for the business. Total cash at the end of the quarter was approximately $3.3 billion. Of this amount, $3.1 billion was classified as cash and cash equivalents. The remaining $168 million is restricted cash, primarily related to cash on deposit in Brazil.
Total inventory at the end of the quarter was $859 million, up $16 million from year-end. Days sales in inventory were 34 days, compared to 30 days for the December quarter. Accounts receivable was essentially flat with the fourth quarter. Days sales outstanding increased sequentially to 46 days from 41 days. This is due largely to changes in geographic and customer mix.
Accounts payable was $1.6 billion, a decrease of $151 million from year-end. Days payable remain unchanged at 62 days.
I'll turn now to our outlook for the second quarter. In mobile devices, we expect sequential growth in smartphones and tablets. We also expect sequential improvement in the operating loss.
In home, on a sequential basis, we expect comparable revenues and operating margins. For Motorola Mobility, we expect approximately $10 million in non-operating expenses and a provision for income taxes in the range of $35 million to $40 million this quarter. In the second quarter, we expect non-GAAP earnings in the range of breakeven to $35 million. This is equivalent to earnings per share of zero to positive $0.12.
With respect to supply, following the tragic events in Japan, we began a detailed review of our supply chain. Our assessment indicates much of our supply chain was unaffected. In impacted areas, we have secured alternative sources of supply or implemented engineering solutions.
While some uncertainty still exists and our review is ongoing, we believe we have a balanced supply outlook reflected in our expectations for the balance of the year. Specifically for the second quarter, we anticipate no significant impact to our mobile device and home businesses.
In addition, I would like to provide the following updates on the full year. In mobile devices, we continue to expect significant revenue growth this year to be driven by the shipment of 20 million to 23 million mobile devices, including 1.5 million to 2 million tablets.
In our home business, we continue to expect revenues in 2011 to be comparable to 2010. And from an operating-margin perspective for the full year, we continue to expect low single-digit operating margin on mobile devices and slight operating margin improvement in home compared to 2010.
For stock compensation expense and amortization of intangibles, we continue to expect approximately $220 million in total expense for the full year. For the second quarter, we expect a total expense of $65 million and in the third and fourth quarters, we expect $52 million and $47 million, respectively.
The quarterly volatility relates to stock compensation expense and has to do with the amount and types of equity compensation, vesting and other factors. With respect to income taxes, we continue to anticipate an ongoing annual effective tax rate of approximately 30%.
As we indicated on the last call, given our expected geographic distribution of operating profits and losses, we expect some volatility in the quarterly tax rate. And on an expense basis, the quarterly tax provision is expected to increase through the year as our business grows. This is due to tax expenses on foreign earnings which, for now, cannot be offset by tax benefits on U.S. operating results.
Over time, as we achieve normalized earning levels across our various geographies and are able to utilize our deferred tax assets, we expect a lower annual tax rate. The earnings guidance we have provided today is on a non-GAAP basis, which excludes stock-based compensation expense, intangible asset amortization and items similar to those historically highlighted in our quarterly earnings results.
With that, I will turn the call back over to Dean to start the questions and answers.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Mark Sue with RBC Capital Markets. Your line is open. Please go ahead.
componenttext: (Operator Instructions) Our first question comes from Mark Sue with RBC Capital Markets. Your line is open. Please go ahead.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sanjay, maybe if you could discuss the factors that you can do at Motorola to kind of put the company in your own hands as opposed to those of the service providers who may see less differentiation among the various Android devices than we do. And I ask t
componenttext: Sanjay, maybe if you could discuss the factors that you can do at Motorola to kind of put the company in your own hands as opposed to those of the service providers who may see less differentiation among the various Android devices than we do. And I ask this, despite the progress you've made so far. It seems increasingly that your success may be determined by the decisions made by Verizon and AT&T.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have certainly worked very, very closely, Mark, with our partners at AT&T and Verizon and that continues to be a very important tenet of our business strategy going forward. But as you say, in the Android ecosystem, there is equally a need for us to di
componenttext:
We have certainly worked very, very closely, Mark, with our partners at AT&T and Verizon and that continues to be a very important tenet of our business strategy going forward. But as you say, in the Android ecosystem, there is equally a need for us to differentiate ourselves and I think if you look at our strategy, there are really four elements to this.
One, you saw with the launch of our ATRIX device with the WebTop and Lapdock, we really think that there is an alternative way of viewing the convergence between mobility and computing. And we will continue to focus on that. You will see multiple devices from us in the second half launching with these capabilities and we will expand the range of our Lapdock devices so we cover a broader price point, addressing both enterprise premium tier as well as more consumer tiers.
Secondly, we will focus on the enterprise segment. We are already seen as the company with the best enterprise offering in the Android ecosystem. With the addition of 3LM and other partners we intend to differentiate ourselves.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sanjay. And as you look to diversify, should we consider a major ramp in your OpEx, which is about $3 billion a year, since each incremental unit at a new carrier will require incremental sales and marketing dollars?
componenttext: Sanjay. And as you look to diversify, should we consider a major ramp in your OpEx, which is about $3 billion a year, since each incremental unit at a new carrier will require incremental sales and marketing dollars?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, my anticipation is that you will not see a large ramp in our OpEx. Certainly, we will make decisions based on opportunities that might come our way, particularly most important one of those, Mark is the potential introduction or expansion of our prese
componenttext: No, my anticipation is that you will not see a large ramp in our OpEx. Certainly, we will make decisions based on opportunities that might come our way, particularly most important one of those, Mark is the potential introduction or expansion of our presence in Europe, but other than that I don't think you should expect a large increase in our OpEx.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you. And good luck gentlemen.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. And good luck gentlemen.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, let me just add that with respect to the OpEx as we previously said, the infrastructure related to our G&A and R&D, we will keep that flat. What we will do is leverage that and as we grow our business, we will put advertising and promotion dollars b
componenttext: Mark, let me just add that with respect to the OpEx as we previously said, the infrastructure related to our G&A and R&D, we will keep that flat. What we will do is leverage that and as we grow our business, we will put advertising and promotion dollars behind our growth. We’ll take our next please.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer & Company. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer & Company. Please go ahead.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks. A couple of clarifications and a question. First, a clarification, Marc, on your slide, page 16, where you do the guidance summary, you talk about tablet units being higher. I mean, did you mean also that smartphone units will be higher sequential
componenttext:
Thanks. A couple of clarifications and a question. First, a clarification, Marc, on your slide, page 16, where you do the guidance summary, you talk about tablet units being higher. I mean, did you mean also that smartphone units will be higher sequentially? And with regard to your 2011 operating margin in mobile devices expecting to be profitable, does that imply that third quarter you expect already a profit in that unit?
And next sort of question, Sanjay, you've talked about your growing presence internationally and I think everyone understands that that's critical for your continued growth, but can you talk about the U.S. market specifically? What kind of challenges are you seeing here in the U.S. market and how do we think about your presence in this market and how do you think that changes through the year?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ittai. With respect to the guidance, let me clarify. Sequentially, smartphone units and tablets will both be up, Q1 to Q2 and for the full year with respect to mobile devices, we will have an operating profit for the full year. We haven't guide
componenttext: Thank you, Ittai. With respect to the guidance, let me clarify. Sequentially, smartphone units and tablets will both be up, Q1 to Q2 and for the full year with respect to mobile devices, we will have an operating profit for the full year. We haven't guided specifically to Q2 or Q3 with that respect.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ittai, with respect to the importance of the U.S. market, it's - in the first quarter, it accounted for 55% of our revenues, the single most important market for us. You have seen us diversify our revenue base with both AT&T as well as with Verizon. And a
componenttext: Ittai, with respect to the importance of the U.S. market, it's - in the first quarter, it accounted for 55% of our revenues, the single most important market for us. You have seen us diversify our revenue base with both AT&T as well as with Verizon. And as we look forward, I anticipate that you will see important launches with Sprint as well and I think that - my anticipation is that our U.S. revenue through the year will certainly grow as we go forward.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ittai. We’ll take our next question please.
componenttext: Thanks, Ittai. We’ll take our next question please.

Can you talk a little bit about how many you think sold through and what the inventory situation looks like in the channel? And then, I've got a quick follow-up to that one as well.

componenttext: Thanks, Rod. This is Marc. With respect to tablets, the XOOM, we shipped over 250,000 in the quarter as you just said. With respect to the sellout, the sellout was good. We had shipped that product late in February, so we only had about five, six weeks of sell through opportunity there. But we were pleased with the levels of stock in channel at the end of the quarter, as well as what we see through this earnings call.

componenttext: Okay. And then, just a follow-up, Sanjay, on your comments on the BIONIC and I guess just to the whole team, actually, does the push out of the BIONIC, does that impact the product line-up plans for the back end of the year or do you just end up with the BIONIC overlapping with those other products you'd already planned to be putting out into the channel in Q3? Can you just talk about that a little bit?

componenttextpreview: Last quarter, you talked a little bit about high end smartphones outperforming the mid-range and low-end smartphone segments relative to your expectations. As you look out through the rest of the year, how do you see that low-end smartphone segment develo
componenttext: Last quarter, you talked a little bit about high end smartphones outperforming the mid-range and low-end smartphone segments relative to your expectations. As you look out through the rest of the year, how do you see that low-end smartphone segment developing and what type of ASP trends are you seeing?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephen. So with respect to the product mix, the smartphone mix, it was more balanced between the high-end and mid-tier this quarter versus last quarter. The comments that we made with respect to last year were more U.S. centric. We enjoyed mor
componenttext: Thank you, Stephen. So with respect to the product mix, the smartphone mix, it was more balanced between the high-end and mid-tier this quarter versus last quarter. The comments that we made with respect to last year were more U.S. centric. We enjoyed more selling and sell through on the high-end performance devices, but as we expand and grow the business outside the U.S., into markets including China and Latin America, we expect a greater mix of these mid-tier devices.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you. And then just a follow-up, if I could. You've talked in the past about a long-term 8% to 12% margin target in handsets. Can you update us on your thinking around that and what type of scale and gross margins you would need to achieve that
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. And then just a follow-up, if I could. You've talked in the past about a long-term 8% to 12% margin target in handsets. Can you update us on your thinking around that and what type of scale and gross margins you would need to achieve that?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have provided previous guidance and we can reaffirm that our long-term targets for operating margins for the combined business are 8% to 12%. It's going to be driven really, in two dynamics. One is we will benefit, obviously from the growth in smartpho
componenttext:
We have provided previous guidance and we can reaffirm that our long-term targets for operating margins for the combined business are 8% to 12%. It's going to be driven really, in two dynamics. One is we will benefit, obviously from the growth in smartphones, but also in the new category of tablets and our goal is to really leverage both the cost structure as well as the cost of goods sold opportunities that we have with respect to improving supply chain efficiencies.
We are focusing a lot on just the pricing disciplines, as well as looking at each product and seeing where we could better leverage the platforms and our components and trying to get some more scale as a result of the increase in sales. So, I won't give any specific comments on gross margin percentage, but clearly we believe that gross margin is an area for us to attack and that could certainly and will help us get to that 8% to 12% long-term operating target that we put out there.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you very much.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys. Thanks. I Appreciate it. A few things. First of all, on the - I know you talked a little bit about the BIONIC and the changes there. Can you go into more detail into possibly what kind of precipitated it and which direction it came from your sid
componenttext: Hi, guys. Thanks. I Appreciate it. A few things. First of all, on the - I know you talked a little bit about the BIONIC and the changes there. Can you go into more detail into possibly what kind of precipitated it and which direction it came from your side or the Verizon side? And then, on the XOOM, the 4G is that kind of the timing over the summer that you had talked about before? I just can't recall exactly how you specified it. And is it possible that the XOOM and the BIONIC, if the timing of 4G on XOOM has anything to do with the change in plan on BIONIC or are they completely different issues, because I know that they both are - they do share this new 4G capability?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ehud, they are related and it has to do with the timing of 4G for us. That was the issue that delayed us. We are engaged with all the LTE providers in the industry and we feel very comfortable with the path forward here. So we believe that we will launch
componenttext: Ehud, they are related and it has to do with the timing of 4G for us. That was the issue that delayed us. We are engaged with all the LTE providers in the industry and we feel very comfortable with the path forward here. So we believe that we will launch both devices with 4G capabilities in the summer here.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, once you saw one, you saw the other and they both come out at the same time?
componenttext: So, once you saw one, you saw the other and they both come out at the same time?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: You got it.
componenttext: You got it.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you talk a little bit about the gross margin on the tablets, Marc? I know in the beginning you talked about gross margin being lower on tablets than they are on smartphones.Are they coming in where you expected them to be and are there any int
componenttext:
Okay. Can you talk a little bit about the gross margin on the tablets, Marc? I know in the beginning you talked about gross margin being lower on tablets than they are on smartphones.
Are they coming in where you expected them to be and are there any intentions on price changes in tablets as we look at tablets for the rest of the year? I think you'd originally talked about bringing the ASP of the XOOM down, correct me if I'm wrong, once this 4G came out and then you talked about new form factors coming out that would also be a lower ASP.
And so, I guess where I'm going at is, A, is that true? And then, B, how does that - your trajectory on the gross margin on tablets change over the course of the year as, A you build volume but, B you come out with lower ASPs so I'm just trying to put all that together to understand what should I be looking at if I model gross margin on tablets between now and the end of the year and then forward and kind of with all those different moving parts?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. There is a couple of questions in there. With respect to the gross margins on the tablets, what we've said and what we saw in Q1 were that the tablet gross margins were lower than the overall gross margins for the business.Secondly, with respect t
componenttext:
Okay. There is a couple of questions in there. With respect to the gross margins on the tablets, what we've said and what we saw in Q1 were that the tablet gross margins were lower than the overall gross margins for the business.
Secondly, with respect to the pricing, clearly we are looking to have multiple devices in the marketplace, multiple form factors, in the second half of this year to move the growth and that will have some impact on the ASPs. I don't see any short term ASP erosion on the products that we launched in the marketplace you know, we have the WiFi tablet as well as the cellular tablet and we'll be expanding with that product outside the U.S. in a more meaningful way in Q2.
The trajectory in the gross margins, I think we're going to have to see how the market plays out with respect to pricing, but we'll continue to look at the cost of our devices and ensure that we have competitive costs and competitive pricing and the gross margin will play itself out, but clearly, this is - there's two things. This is accretive to our business we're leveraging both the research and development of the platform, as well as the existing infrastructure, Ehud, of the organization.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So these new tablets that come out will all basically be priced so they have the same gross margin as your current ones? I'm just wondering if as they come out with lower ASPs, will they be lower gross margin or we should look at all of your tablets, all
componenttext: So these new tablets that come out will all basically be priced so they have the same gross margin as your current ones? I'm just wondering if as they come out with lower ASPs, will they be lower gross margin or we should look at all of your tablets, all portfolios being one gross margin.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's a reasonable assumption for now. I'll provide more guidance as we progress into the second half of the year.
componenttext: I think that's a reasonable assumption for now. I'll provide more guidance as we progress into the second half of the year.

componenttext: Great. Thank you.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We’ll go to Brian Modoff with Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys. Yeah. Sanjay, you had Nokia guide down the unit volumes about 10% sequentially. You've had RIM tonight pre-announce negatively. You're talking about kind of an incremental approach to your distribution and marketing expansion. Don’t you think
componenttext:
Hi, guys. Yeah. Sanjay, you had Nokia guide down the unit volumes about 10% sequentially. You've had RIM tonight pre-announce negatively. You're talking about kind of an incremental approach to your distribution and marketing expansion. Don’t you think time is not on your side in terms of these other competitors who are perhaps getting their act together eventually and being more competitive?
Right now, you have an opportunity to gain share in places like Europe. There’s - really, there isn’t a big presence there, and while it’s certainly China 25% of your unit volumes is a good start there, don’t you think that maybe you should be more aggressive internationally in trying to gain share in markets where you’re not really that strong?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, that’s a very good question. As you’ve seen in this quarter, we pretty meaningfully increased our revenue base outside of the U.S. About 44% of our revenue this quarter came from outside of the U.S. It was really driven by three factors, growth
componenttext:
Brian, that’s a very good question. As you’ve seen in this quarter, we pretty meaningfully increased our revenue base outside of the U.S. About 44% of our revenue this quarter came from outside of the U.S. It was really driven by three factors, growth in Latin America, more specifically Brazil; growth in China, as you mentioned and also growth in international markets.
With respect specifically to your comments regarding Europe, at the moment we have DEFY, which is our best seller in Europe, ATRIX launches in Germany with Vodafone and the PhoneWarehouse - the PhoneHouse, rather, and we have tablet launches in UK with Carphone Warehouse, Best Buy and obviously part of Best Buy, and Dixons. Germany, we launched the XOOM with Deutsche Telecom. We have launches coming up in France and Italy. We are certainly expanding our presence in the second quarter in Germany.
As we look to second half, we’re going to focus on Germany, France, and the UK as some of the key markets for expanding our presence. We have some very good carrier interest, as well as expanded retail distribution. And over the course of next quarter, we will determine how much advertising and promotion dollars we will invest as we solidify some of our deals with carriers, as well as retail for our second-half portfolio.
But your point is very well taken and understood, and we are evaluating very, very carefully how much we will invest in Europe, but we are already expanding our presence in Europe.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, real quickly, can you talk sequentially how your smartphones did in North America? Obviously, there was some concern with Verizon and the iPhone. Give us a little more color around how your smartphone unit volumes did sequentially from Q4 in Nor
componenttext: And then, real quickly, can you talk sequentially how your smartphones did in North America? Obviously, there was some concern with Verizon and the iPhone. Give us a little more color around how your smartphone unit volumes did sequentially from Q4 in North America.

componenttextpreview: You could see from some of the guidance that we gave today with the 50:50 mix of Smartphones between North America and outside the U.S., there was relatively flatness in terms of that growth in North America.
componenttext: You could see from some of the guidance that we gave today with the 50:50 mix of Smartphones between North America and outside the U.S., there was relatively flatness in terms of that growth in North America.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Sanjay, now that you’ve had a few months of head-to-head with the CDMA iPhone with Verizon and the iPad 2, any color on how this strategy of offering different versions of products to resonate with different consumer groups holds up against, lik
componenttext: Thanks. Sanjay, now that you’ve had a few months of head-to-head with the CDMA iPhone with Verizon and the iPad 2, any color on how this strategy of offering different versions of products to resonate with different consumer groups holds up against, like, Apple’s one-size-fits-all? It’s a bit more expensive approach than doing, like, one SKU, and you are small and don’t have a supply chain. Would you modify that at all? Are you concentrating in some sweet spots or are you still going to try and hit it across the entire product roadmap?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, I think going forward we continue to believe that one size doesn’t fit all. And the range of Smartphones that we see selling well in the U.S. still continues to be relatively narrow. But as you’ve seen, we have offered differentiated offerings lik
componenttext:
Ed, I think going forward we continue to believe that one size doesn’t fit all. And the range of Smartphones that we see selling well in the U.S. still continues to be relatively narrow. But as you’ve seen, we have offered differentiated offerings like ATRIX, which extends the capability of Smartphones to more broadly applicable situations for consumers and that has resonated very well.
I will tell you that in surveys that we’ve done, the ATRIX users have shown a great deal of satisfaction with the value proposition of that product. The enterprise is obviously going to be very, very important for us, as I highlighted earlier.
The second thing I would say is that we see mid-tier becoming very important in international markets. China, Brazil, and Europe, we see mid-tier being very important. The success of DEFY in all three regions really underlines two points. One, the price point of that device is right, and the life proof value proposition is resonating. So, I think that we will continue to be very selective about the markets and consumer segments that we go after but it’s unlikely that we will consolidate into one device. You will see us consolidating into fewer devices than we did, perhaps, in the past, but by no means one device.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So, that brings up the second question. You mentioned your 7 million users now for BLUR and a lot of your differentiation involves around, like you pointed out, social collaboration, content management, and cloud storage. Is it just going to take longer f
componenttext: So, that brings up the second question. You mentioned your 7 million users now for BLUR and a lot of your differentiation involves around, like you pointed out, social collaboration, content management, and cloud storage. Is it just going to take longer for these things to bear fruit? Because you are taking a rather differentiated approach to the whole mobility computing smartphone aspect of it. I am just trying to get a feel for when, if this takes off, you expect to see significant gains in users on both your services and also in new units in some of these areas?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It’s a very good question, Ed. Unfortunately, I don’t have a very good answer. I don’t know. I think we believe that these are the things that will resonate with consumers, and we continue to focus on it. Exactly when that begins to make a meaningfu
componenttext:
It’s a very good question, Ed. Unfortunately, I don’t have a very good answer. I don’t know. I think we believe that these are the things that will resonate with consumers, and we continue to focus on it. Exactly when that begins to make a meaningful difference in the marketplace, I think that would be hard for me to pinpoint right now, except to say that we will continue to focus on multimedia everywhere, enterprise and mobile computing approach that we have taken here.
So, those three, and supported by our BLUR service, are the four main things that we’ll focus on.

componenttext: Thanks a lot.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks so much. Just a couple of questions on your international business. First, how has your thought process about Europe and some of the other international markets changed given Nokia’s disruption? And in particular, how have your conversations
componenttext: Hi, thanks so much. Just a couple of questions on your international business. First, how has your thought process about Europe and some of the other international markets changed given Nokia’s disruption? And in particular, how have your conversations with the carriers changed in those regions, if at all?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Simona, in Brazil and in Latin America, Nokia has always had a pretty meaningful presence. We’ve expanded our presence and we’ve seen a slight decline in Nokia’s position in these regions. In Europe, I think their numbers have been published. We’r
componenttext:
Simona, in Brazil and in Latin America, Nokia has always had a pretty meaningful presence. We’ve expanded our presence and we’ve seen a slight decline in Nokia’s position in these regions. In Europe, I think their numbers have been published. We’re beginning to see much more interest from carriers, perhaps unrelated to what is happening with Nokia, but certainly we are seeing a little more interest from carriers in Europe as well.
In China, I think we have much better distribution through our retail channels and we have much better relationship with China Telecom, China Mobile and China Unicom. Those things are driving our revenue in these regions, Simona.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: But I mean, just in terms of the relative change, if any, have you perceived any improved traction or greater interest or more engaged discussions with the carriers since Nokia’s announcement, or do you feel like things are unfolding like they would’v
componenttext: But I mean, just in terms of the relative change, if any, have you perceived any improved traction or greater interest or more engaged discussions with the carriers since Nokia’s announcement, or do you feel like things are unfolding like they would’ve, regardless of Nokia’s announcement?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don’t think I can pinpoint any events that have occurred or any conversations to what has happened at Nokia. I think there is continued interest in what we are delivering. In a lot of ways, I think there’s interest in the value propositions that we
componenttext: I don’t think I can pinpoint any events that have occurred or any conversations to what has happened at Nokia. I think there is continued interest in what we are delivering. In a lot of ways, I think there’s interest in the value propositions that we are offering and the price points that we can make them - those offers at.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then just the other quick follow-up was on margins. So when we compare your margins, your gross margins, in your U.S. business versus the international markets, how do they compare? And I guess I mean both on a blended basis, so I would assume that
componenttext: Okay. Then just the other quick follow-up was on margins. So when we compare your margins, your gross margins, in your U.S. business versus the international markets, how do they compare? And I guess I mean both on a blended basis, so I would assume that international is lower than U.S., but I’d like to confirm that, and then also on a like-for-like basis. So when you sell an ATRIX in China or Brazil versus in the U.S., does that ATRIX internationally have a lower or similar growth margin than in the U.S.?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Simona. So, with respect to the margin profiles between the U.S. and outside the U.S., generally speaking, the U.S. has been more favorable. That obviously gets impacted by product mix. With respect to specific products, I am not comfortable talki
componenttext: Thanks, Simona. So, with respect to the margin profiles between the U.S. and outside the U.S., generally speaking, the U.S. has been more favorable. That obviously gets impacted by product mix. With respect to specific products, I am not comfortable talking about any specific products at this point.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi. I have just a question - first, a clarification of something you said before. Are you - do you still intend to use your own internal solution for LTE or is it - is there any change in strategy that you discussed before? Then, my question is about ASPs
componenttext: Hi. I have just a question - first, a clarification of something you said before. Are you - do you still intend to use your own internal solution for LTE or is it - is there any change in strategy that you discussed before? Then, my question is about ASPs. As you go into China and Latin America, what do you think will happen to Smartphone ASPs? Is the average ASP for Smartphones in these target markets substantially lower or the same with the current - versus the current ASPs? Thanks.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tal, I would say we are engaged with all the major providers of LTE solutions, and I anticipate that we would use at least one, if not more, external solutions.
componenttext: Tal, I would say we are engaged with all the major providers of LTE solutions, and I anticipate that we would use at least one, if not more, external solutions.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Tal, with respect to the ASPs, you saw that our ASPs were up $15, up to $229 this quarter. That was related to the tablets. But specifically to your question about regional mix, China and elsewhere, it’s going to really be dependent more on the prod
componenttext:
And Tal, with respect to the ASPs, you saw that our ASPs were up $15, up to $229 this quarter. That was related to the tablets. But specifically to your question about regional mix, China and elsewhere, it’s going to really be dependent more on the product categories.
In Smartphones, we’re selling more of the mid-tier type devices, and those, of course, have a lower ASP. But overall, I think the trend continues to be positive for us on the ASP side. As we said, we’ll be expecting to ship sequentially more tablets and expect the trend in ASPs to continue, and I’ll give you more details as we progress through the year.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you have any sense of channel inventory for handsets for you? You said that North America was flat, which is a pretty bullish number. Is it channel inventory or is it the sell-through, what do you think, in the U.S.?
componenttext: And do you have any sense of channel inventory for handsets for you? You said that North America was flat, which is a pretty bullish number. Is it channel inventory or is it the sell-through, what do you think, in the U.S.?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me answer it - this way. I can answer an overall channel point or stocking channel. The stocking channels are very normalized levels really across the globe, as well as North America, and in terms of what I commented earlier on was specifically on tab
componenttext: Let me answer it - this way. I can answer an overall channel point or stocking channel. The stocking channels are very normalized levels really across the globe, as well as North America, and in terms of what I commented earlier on was specifically on tablets, where we shifted 250,000 - approximately 250,000 tablets in Q1. We were very pleased with the sell-through through the quarter end and through the earnings call.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thank you. Sanjay, I was hoping if you could elaborate maybe a little more on your enterprise strategy. When do you think we start to see Motorola make a meaningful dent into the enterprise market, and what exactly is your angle into this end segment?
componenttext: Hi. Thank you. Sanjay, I was hoping if you could elaborate maybe a little more on your enterprise strategy. When do you think we start to see Motorola make a meaningful dent into the enterprise market, and what exactly is your angle into this end segment?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Amitabh, I won't give you a precise timing except to say that I think that we have invested more in making sure that we have both the security, the mobile device management and integration of services which are - and applications, which are important for
componenttext:
Amitabh, I won't give you a precise timing except to say that I think that we have invested more in making sure that we have both the security, the mobile device management and integration of services which are - and applications, which are important for enterprises than, I believe, anyone else in the Android ecosystem.
And we are getting trials by multiple Fortune 500 companies right now. So I think the timing is unclear, and as you know, some of these trials take longer and some take shorter. So, that will play out over the course of this year, but there is a very large focus, both organizationally as well as in terms of feature set of our devices to ensure that we address the enterprise market place.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if I could just ask a follow-up, I think you said your U.S. share was 55% in the first quarter. I suspect international probably grows to a larger proportion in the second quarter. Should we expect the U.S. market again to come back for you in the bac
componenttext: And if I could just ask a follow-up, I think you said your U.S. share was 55% in the first quarter. I suspect international probably grows to a larger proportion in the second quarter. Should we expect the U.S. market again to come back for you in the back half once you introduced products like the Bionic?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: You know, it’s - what we’ve guided to is overall improvement in sales for the quarter, and overall I've given guidance relative to 20 million to 23 million devices, including tablets. I haven’t been specific today. If you’d allow me to provide tha
componenttext:
You know, it’s - what we’ve guided to is overall improvement in sales for the quarter, and overall I've given guidance relative to 20 million to 23 million devices, including tablets. I haven’t been specific today. If you’d allow me to provide that color later in the year, I would be more comfortable doing that.
I did want to clarify an earlier comment that Brian Modoff had asked relative to the North American shipments, Q4 to Q1. I may have misunderstood that and I said it was flattish. The shipments, as expected, in smartphones were down from Q4 to Q1. That's reflective of the mix that we also reported on, 50%-50% mix in Q2, North America, relative to the rest of the regions.

componenttext: Good evening. This is Sam Elnean on behalf of Jim Suva. On the delay of the BIONIC, was it a hardware chip side issue or a software issue or a response to the competitive landscape? Can we get some more details around that?

componenttext: Sam, it was really a software issue of getting the performance to a place that both ourselves and our partner, Verizon Wireless, were comfortable launching the device. And as you understand, there's a great deal of complexity in launching any new technology like this and that was probably the main matter at heart here.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is actually Deepak Sitaraman for Kulbinder. Sanjay, for mobile devices, your full-year outlook for low single-digit operating margin implies that you can exit the year with the margin that's somewhere in the high single digits, I guess, first of all,
componenttext: This is actually Deepak Sitaraman for Kulbinder. Sanjay, for mobile devices, your full-year outlook for low single-digit operating margin implies that you can exit the year with the margin that's somewhere in the high single digits, I guess, first of all, is that the right way to think about this? And if so, can you talk about the visibility you have there? What are some of the puts and takes to get there and specifically, what visibility do you have on carrier support, especially in the U.S. market in the back half of the year? Thank you.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Deepak, this is Marc. Let me add a few comments and then Sanjay could add some more color. With respect to the guidance on mobile devices, what we said was that we would have a single-digit operating profit for the full year. That's correct. I didn't prov
componenttext:
Deepak, this is Marc. Let me add a few comments and then Sanjay could add some more color. With respect to the guidance on mobile devices, what we said was that we would have a single-digit operating profit for the full year. That's correct. I didn't provide the color between each quarter.
I think you'll have to allow us to progress on that one as well. Let's report on Q2, which will be favorable in terms of our expectations from Q1 and with respect to the product roadmap, some of the design wins that we have some visibility to in the second half of this year, we're optimistic about the expectations that we've laid out.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe Deepak, I could just add a couple more comments. I think you wanted a little more color, specifically with respect to United States. I feel very comfortable with the level of traction and the design wins that we are getting and the level of interest
componenttext:
Maybe Deepak, I could just add a couple more comments. I think you wanted a little more color, specifically with respect to United States. I feel very comfortable with the level of traction and the design wins that we are getting and the level of interest we're getting. As you know, we're now in April.
So things are proceeding on plan for me to be comfortable with how fourth quarter will play out in terms of design-in and the issues, of course, as you probably understand it very well, is execution of my product in time, quality, marketing and sell-through. Those are issues that will determine how well we'll perform in fourth quarter from here.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Next question, please.
componenttext: Thank you. Next question, please.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We’ll go to the line of Jeff Kvaal with Barclays Capital. Please go ahead.
componenttext: We’ll go to the line of Jeff Kvaal with Barclays Capital. Please go ahead.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks very much. Sanjay, I wanted to circle back a little bit to the execution question that you brought up in your opening remarks. And I think an outside observer would note that, particularly on LTE, there's a bit of a time-to-market disadvantage
componenttext: Yes. Thanks very much. Sanjay, I wanted to circle back a little bit to the execution question that you brought up in your opening remarks. And I think an outside observer would note that, particularly on LTE, there's a bit of a time-to-market disadvantages that you folks are now suffering from. Could you help us think through that? Obviously, in an Android market, one would think that time-to-market is going to be critical and hopefully there are some learnings there for you and we shouldn't necessarily expect this to be a regular push-out situation.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jeff, I'd be disappointed if this became a regular event. As you know, we launched our first smartphone in October of 2009. And since then, we've delivered altogether 27 smartphones into the marketplace. I won't say that every single one of them was
componenttext:
Yes. Jeff, I'd be disappointed if this became a regular event. As you know, we launched our first smartphone in October of 2009. And since then, we've delivered altogether 27 smartphones into the marketplace. I won't say that every single one of them was on time, but I would certainly say that our execution track record has been good.
So, I would certainly view this push-out of our LTE devices, both as XOOM LTE as well as DROID BIONIC, as an aberration and having launched multiple different devices on new technologies, I'm very diligent about making sure that we pay particular attention to this matter. So, I think I was keen to point to you that that execution flaw was an aberration rather than a course of business.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks and then also, I'm wondering, have you updated your thinking about the mid-tier market here in North America?
componenttext: Okay. Thanks and then also, I'm wondering, have you updated your thinking about the mid-tier market here in North America?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there is little doubt now that there is a developing mid-tier market in U.S. I would say with the introduction of LTE and 4G devices, there is equally a creation of - you have seen 249 and 299 tier devices. So, I think that as we see the developme
componenttext: I think there is little doubt now that there is a developing mid-tier market in U.S. I would say with the introduction of LTE and 4G devices, there is equally a creation of - you have seen 249 and 299 tier devices. So, I think that as we see the development of mid-tier, we've also seen, if anything, slight expansion in the capabilities and features of high-tier devices. So, I would say as we go forward, those two will be significant trends, I think, in the industry.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Jeff, will take your next question.
componenttext: Thanks. Jeff, will take your next question.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Guys, can you walk us through, in terms of scale and how we see that path of improving margins based on sort of some commentary you've made. Is it the volume ramp purchasing power alone, do you feel like component pricing doing a favor to be an
componenttext: Thank you. Guys, can you walk us through, in terms of scale and how we see that path of improving margins based on sort of some commentary you've made. Is it the volume ramp purchasing power alone, do you feel like component pricing doing a favor to be and thinking about that that's the key critical lever here, is it volume alone, or is it number of (inaudible) understand the (inaudible) and what are the levers that move margins in the right direction?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter. You were breaking up a little bit on the question, but I think I have most of it. With respect to the growth in scale, clearly leveraging the organization, as I've said previously, is going to be very, very important to driving the 8% to 12
componenttext:
Thanks, Peter. You were breaking up a little bit on the question, but I think I have most of it. With respect to the growth in scale, clearly leveraging the organization, as I've said previously, is going to be very, very important to driving the 8% to 12%. Having said that, we absolutely are going after the product cost, driving it both with the increased volume, we'll get synergies and benefits from the higher volume, both across - many places in the supply chain, including manufacturing. But we also are putting in new disciplines and we're attacking the product specifically in terms of components and platforming and looking for leverage on that front as well.
Just a couple of items again and again, there is always puts and takes with this. But on the puts side, we are also looking at improving from the end-of-life thing and the quality metrics around our devices. We can see, really, over the last several quarters the amount of inventory that we've had to dispose of without utilization has gone down significantly. We see that trend continuing to be favorable as our end-of-lifeing of product becomes much more manageable and efficient.
Having said that, the mix relative to the U.S. and outside the U.S. could have some impact on the gross margin, not necessarily because of the regionalization, just because we expect that there will be a higher level of mid-tier devices in the international market. So, I can't give you any specific gross margin, but really with respect to scale and pulling down gross margin dollars and profits, those are some areas that we're focused on.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Sanjay, why don’t you [ph] give us an update on the strategy with the feature phone business right now. Is that something we should expect to trail off or not? And then, secondly, any greater detail on kind of your position in China? I think you
componenttext: Thanks. Sanjay, why don’t you [ph] give us an update on the strategy with the feature phone business right now. Is that something we should expect to trail off or not? And then, secondly, any greater detail on kind of your position in China? I think you mentioned you were leading Android share there. I want to make sure I heard that right. And I was wondering if it is heavily skewed towards one of the carriers or are you seeing strength at all three? Thanks.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tavis, as I think indicated before to you and others, we have a gentleman, actually his name is Say Lu [ph] who is based out of China, who drives what we call mass-market consumer products, MMCP and mass-market smartphone products, MMSP and Say Liu [ph] h
componenttext:
Tavis, as I think indicated before to you and others, we have a gentleman, actually his name is Say Lu [ph] who is based out of China, who drives what we call mass-market consumer products, MMCP and mass-market smartphone products, MMSP and Say Liu [ph] has been an important factor in driving our growth in Latin America, as well as in China. And actually, that part of the business is proceeding very well, I would say ahead of plan, in terms of its traction in the marketplace. So, I would say both the feature phone as well as the mass-market smartphone categories are continuing to perform well for us.
In terms of China, again, you heard us right. We are the leading ANDROID handset provider in China. As you know, we have a great deal of support from local application providers. We have our own shop for apps in China, which differentiates our device.
We have relationships with all three carriers there. And certainly our China Telecom XT800 device has done extremely well for us. But DEFY is also doing extremely well in multiple carrier networks. So I don't think there is very heavy differentiation amongst carrier relationships there in China.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you so much for joining us on the call. During the first quarter, we continued our momentum. We grew the mobile devices business by 30%. We broadened our sales mix. We launched two new experiences with the ATRIX and XOOM and delivered a strong
componenttext:
Well, thank you so much for joining us on the call. During the first quarter, we continued our momentum. We grew the mobile devices business by 30%. We broadened our sales mix. We launched two new experiences with the ATRIX and XOOM and delivered a strong quarter in the home business.
Our priorities going forward are to differentiate ourselves in the Android ecosystem, leading the transition to IP-based video solutions and develop new experiences for consumers and the enterprise. With consistent execution and by leveraging our brand, distribution and strong balance sheet, I hope we will continue to grow our topline and improve our financial results. Thank you so much for joining us again.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sanjay. I want to remind everyone that an audio replay on today's slide presentation will be available on the Motorola Mobility website shortly after this call.During this call, we've made a number of forward-looking statements within the meanin
componenttext:
Thanks, Sanjay. I want to remind everyone that an audio replay on today's slide presentation will be available on the Motorola Mobility website shortly after this call.
During this call, we've made a number of forward-looking statements within the meaning of applicable federal securities law. Forward-looking statements are any statements that are not historical facts and are based on our current expectations and should not be relied upon as representing our views as of any subsequent date. We can give no assurance that any future results or events discussed will be achieved.
Such forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, the following - guidance from Motorola Mobility's future performance; future strategic plans, including our software and OS strategy, potential cost reductions, expected timing for the announcement, launch and shipment of new products. Expectations for the volume and financial impact of product shipments, including smartphones and tablets; guidance for our future revenue, operating margin, expenses, cash position, tax rate, margins, profitability, ASPs, R&D spend, demand trends, or market share and expectations on growth; supply availability; and the impact of recent events in Japan.
Because forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties, Motorola Mobility's actual results could differ materially from those stated in such statements. Information about the factors that could cause and in some cases have caused and such differences can be found in today's press release, 2010 10-K and our other SEC filings.
Thank you for joining us today. This now concludes our call.

componenttext: Good afternoon, and thank you for holding. Today’s call is being recorded. If you have any objections please disconnect at this time.
