componenttext:
During this call, we made a number of forward-looking statements within the meaning of applicable federal securities law. Forward looking statements are any statements that are not historical facts. These statements are based on the current expectations of Motorola Mobility and we can give no assurance that any future results or events discussed will be achieved. Any forward-looking statements represent only our views as of today and should not be relied upon as representing our views and any subsequent date. Forward-looking statements include, but not limited to, our comments in answers related to the following topics: guidance on Motorola Mobility's future performance, future strategic plans, potential cost reduction, announcement launch shipment of new products, expectations for the volumes and financial impact of handset shipments including smartphones, guidance for future sales and operating expenses, expected cash position, margins and profitability, ASPN demand trends or market share. 
In addition, our tax rate, R&D pending, expectations around operating systems strategy, expectations for the tablet market and software strategy. These forward-looking statements involve this case, Motorola Mobility's actual results could differ materially from these forward-looking statements. Information about factors that could cause and in some cases would have caused such differences can be found in today's press release on Pages 13 through 36 of Motorola Mobility's information statement and of Motorola Mobility's other SEC filings. Thank you for joining us today. This concludes our conference call.

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for holding. Today’s call is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. The presentation material and additional financial tables are currently posted on Motorola Mobility’s Investor Relations website.
In addition, a replay of this call will be available approximately 3 hours after the conclusion of this call on our Investor Relations website at investors.motorola.com. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to introduce Mr. Dean Lindroth, Corporate Vice President and Investor Relations Officer. Mr. Lindroth, you may begin your conference.

componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to Motorola Mobility’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference Call.Today’s call will include prepared remarks by Sanjay Jha, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Marc Rothman, Chief Financial Officer. Dan Molon
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. Welcome to Motorola Mobility’s Fourth Quarter Results Conference Call.
Today’s call will include prepared remarks by Sanjay Jha, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Marc Rothman, Chief Financial Officer. Dan Moloney, President of Motorola Mobility, will join for the Q&A portion of the call.
Today’s presentation includes a number of forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are any statements that are not historical facts. These forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations and there can be no assurance that such expectations will prove to be correct. Because forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties, actual results could differ materially from these statements. Information about factors that could cause, and in some cases have caused such differences, can be found in our registration statement and in today's press release.
The content of this presentation contains time-sensitive information that is accurate only as of date thereof. We will not be reviewing or updating this material, should this presentation be retransmitted for participants at a later date. I'll now turn the call over to Sanjay.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dean. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us today for the first Motorola Mobility earnings call. After 2-plus years of planning and a lot of hard work by employees from around the world, Motorola is separated into 2 publicly traded companies
componenttext:
Thanks, Dean. Good afternoon and thank you for joining us today for the first Motorola Mobility earnings call. After 2-plus years of planning and a lot of hard work by employees from around the world, Motorola is separated into 2 publicly traded companies on January 4, 2011. As an independent company, we will focus on growth as we transform the organization by strengthening our team with new talented leadership delivering differentiated products and services and leveraging the Motorola brand name. 
Our brand will represent a simple message, that by making technology intuitive and easy to use, and enabling consumers to connect with people and things that matter to them, we can simplify and enrich people's lives. Our growth will be driven by smartphones, tablets, and over time, converged experiences in the home and on the go. As we innovate and grow, we plan to leverage our cost structure, achieve full year operating profitability in mobile devices in 2011 and improve our overall annual operating margin to 8% to 12% over the longer term. With that, I will comment on our fourth quarter business result and then discuss opportunities for growth and strategic priorities. Following that, Mark will discuss our financial results in more detail and our guidance. 
Fourth quarter revenues and operating earnings grew sequentially and year-on-year. On total revenues of $3.4 billion, we generated a non-GAAP operating profit of $146 million compared to a loss in the year-ago quarter, and we generated $225 million in cash from operation. In mobile devices, we shipped 4.9 million smartphones in the quarter, bringing our total to 13.7 million for the year. On a non-GAAP basis, mobile devices generated an operating profit of $56 million. In fourth quarter, we launched 7 new smartphones in markets around the world, including the DROID Pro, DROID 2 Global, BRAVO and DEFY. This brought our total smartphone launches last year to 23. 
North America accounted for 63% of our total revenue compared to 69% in the fourth quarter of 2009. Demand for DROID 2 and DROID X continued to be strong. Sales of midrange smartphones, including BRAVO and DEFY was solid, but slightly below our expectations. Aside from North America, smartphone shipments grew by over 50% sequentially and accounted for over 30% of total smartphone units. In China, our second largest market, we saw very strong sequential growth in the quarter. During the year, we introduced over 20 smartphones, including the XP800 with China Telecom, several OPhone devices with China Mobile and a refreshed lineup introduced under our main brand. For the full year, we shipped nearly 2 million smartphones across the 3 network operators.
In Latin America, as well as in certain markets in Europe, fourth quarter smartphone volumes were also higher sequentially, led by sales of DEFY and other midrange smartphones. Globally, we have deployed BLUR-enabled devices to over 40 carriers and we have approximately 6 million subscribers. This service, which provides consumers with push Internet content and operated with network-efficient devices, continues to be an integral part of our differentiation strategy. During the quarter, we acquired Vector, our fifth acquisition of innovative software technology in 2010. By integrating Vector's capabilities into BLUR, we will enable consumers to enjoy on-demand access to the additional media across multiple devices and provide enhanced content security. 
Shifting now to this year. We began 2011 with the announcement of 3 new smartphones and our first tablet. This included the ATRIX 4G, which will initially launch with AT&T and subsequently with Bell Canada, Orange and others. For Verizon, we announced the DROID BIONIC, our first LTE smartphone, and XOOM, the first tablet on Honeycomb, an Android release designed specifically to deliver a unique tablet experience. 
Each of these devices inspired by a leading edge dual-core processor providing 2 gigahertz of processing power. Feedback on these new devices has been very positive and includes a variety of awards at the recent Consumer Electronics Show. The ATRIX 4G and the upgradable version of XOOM, which we'll begin to ship by the end of the February. The LTE version of XOOM and DROID BIONIC are expected to ship in the second quarter. From a broader portfolio perspective, our growth this year will be driven by compelling product growth map. 
First, smartphones. In North America, we will focus on smartphones as the leading edge technology that delivers the best consumer and enterprise experience as possible. In China, smartphone demand is growing rapidly in midrange devices, as well as in the high tier. We will continue to address both segments and all deployed technologies in China. 
In Latin America, we see the opportunity for growth predominantly in midrange smartphones. And for the near term, we will address opportunities in Europe in select markets as we did in 2010. To serve consumers needing enterprise functionality, we will continue to deliver retail features on top of Android that provides security capabilities essential to CIOs. With DROID Pro and other high-performance smartphones, we'll provide the enterprise-ready alternative these consumers have been looking for. 
From a feature phone and voice-centric devices perspective, we will continue to be focused on a limited number of devices to address the basic market opportunities. In iDEN, we'll continue to refresh the portfolio for our U.S. and international customers. 
Finally, the convergence of mobility and computing opens up a new area of growth for us. The ATRIX 4G smartphone with docking accessories and the XOOM tablet are the first examples of how we are beginning to address this opportunity. ATRIX 4G is more than just a high-performance smartphone. When combined with this unique docking accessories and enabled by our proprietary Webtop application, it enables and enhance a more interactive experiences. For example, paired with a laptop dock, consumers can have the large screen experience for consumption of HD content, editing documents and browsing the web. The XOOM tablet provides best-in-class performance, HD display enrich graphics. It opens up new and innovative services and takes media consumption and gaming to a new level. 
 
Growing for profitability in smartphones and tablets is possible by building on our momentum and differentiating our devices. We intend to do this by staying at the leading-edge hardware innovation; by providing unique services and experience that includes social collaboration, content management and delivery and cloud storage and by integrating essential enterprise capabilities on top of the fastest growing mobile platform. Consistently executing and this set of priorities in conjunction with our brand, intellectual property and carrier relationship is what will set us apart, enable our growth and drive operating profit improvements in mobile devices. 
Now turning to Home. Fourth quarter total revenues were up sequentially, reflecting solid demand for HD and DVR set-top. From a product portfolio perspective, we launched the industry's highest density upstream DOCSIS solution and a next-generation IP set-top for the Europe market, extending our leadership position in IPTV. We also expanded our software solution suite with the introduction of our EDGE Home Center. This cloud-based solution enables consumers to manage their home network, mobile devices and services from home or remotely. 
During the quarter, we acquired 4Home, the developer of a software platform for managed services in the home. By integrating their capabilities with our cloud-based media service manager software portfolio, we can begin to enable consumer converged experiences, that include home energy management, security, monitoring and control.  
Looking back at 2010, macroeconomic conditions in U.S. provided a headwind for the industry. After a challenging start to the year, we began to see demand for our set-top boxes stabilize in the second half. In infrastructure, revenue grew last year as operator showed us solutions for the network capacity and advanced services. Overall, the team performed well in a difficult environment by holding share in our priority market, including innovative products, reducing cost while continuing to invest in future technology and improving profitability. 
As we look ahead in Home, we expect a mid-single-digit CAGR for the industry over the next several years, as economic conditions improve and demand recovers. That said, in 2011, we expect industry demand to be relatively flat compared to 2010. Our priorities will include sustaining our leadership in advanced set-tops and gateways and prioritizing our investment in IP-based home solutions, next generation content delivery, cloud-based services and multiscreen experiences. In addition, we plan to continue to improve operating margin as we further streamline our product portfolio and manage our cost. 
I'll turn the call over now to Marc to provide additional details on financial results for the quarter and our guidance. Marc?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sanjay. Motorola Mobility revenues were $3.4 billion in the fourth quarter, up 16% sequentially and up 21% from the fourth quarter of 2009. For the full year, revenues were $11.5 billion, up 4% compared to 2009. On a GAAP basis, fourth quarter ope
componenttext:
Thanks, Sanjay. Motorola Mobility revenues were $3.4 billion in the fourth quarter, up 16% sequentially and up 21% from the fourth quarter of 2009. For the full year, revenues were $11.5 billion, up 4% compared to 2009. On a GAAP basis, fourth quarter operating earnings were $126 million. Non-GAAP adjustments for operating earnings were net expense of $20 million. This includes stock compensation and intangible assets amortization expense of $57 million and a restructuring charge of $18 million, offset by income of $55 million related to an IP seller. 
Fourth quarter non-GAAP operating earnings were $146 million compared to $80 million in the third quarter and a loss of $46 million in the year-ago quarter. For the full year, we generated operating earnings on both a GAAP and non-GAAP basis compared to the significant loss incurred in 2009. On a per share basis, using 294.3 million shares outstanding, we reported fourth quarter GAAP net earnings of $0.27 per share compared to a loss of $0.69 per share in the year-ago quarter. On a non-GAAP basis, fourth quarter net earnings were $0.37 per share compared to a loss of $0.24 per share in the fourth quarter of 2009. Further details on our non-GAAP results are included in our today's press release and available on our website. 
My remaining income statement references will be on a non-GAAP basis. Our overall gross margin percentage in the quarter was 27%, comparable with the third quarter and up from 25.5% in the fourth quarter of 2009. For the full year, we improved gross margin percentage to 26.2% from 19.9% in 2009. This was driven primarily by shifting our mix to higher margins smartphones from lower margin feature phones, and improved supply chain efficiencies. In addition, Home gross margin increased driven by improved product mix and product cost reduction actions. 
Total operating expenses in the quarter were up 8% sequentially. The increase was driven primarily by sales and marketing expenses to support business growth and new product introductions in mobile devices. Compared to 2009, total OpEx for the quarter and the full year were comparable. Total net interest expense in the quarter was $12 million, reflecting an allocation of net interest cost from our former parent company. 
Turning now to our business segments. In Mobile Devices, fourth quarter revenues were $2.4 billion, up 33% year-over-year. Total shipments were 11.3 million units, including 4.9 million smartphones. As we anticipated, our overall ASP declined to $214 compared to $223 in the third quarter. This was driven by midrange devices, representing a larger portion of our total smartphone volume. For the full year, Mobile Device revenues were $7.8 billion, up 9% compared to 2009, driven by the shipment of 13.7 million smartphones compared to 2 million in 2009. 
In Mobile Devices, we generated a $56 million operating profit in the quarter compared to a $3 million profit in the third quarter of 2010. Our sequential improvement was driven by higher smartphone volumes offset partially by higher sales and marketing expenses. For the full year, with growth in smartphones, improvement in gross margin and tight control over our operating expenses, we reduced mobile devices operating loss for the full year to $198 million from $924 million in 2009. 
Now in the Home business. Fourth quarter revenues were $1 billion, up 10% sequentially and 1% year-over-year. On a sequential basis, set-top revenue was up 21%, offset partially by slightly lower infrastructure sales. For the full year, revenue in our Home business was $3.6 billion, down 7% from 2009. Sales of consumer equipment were lower, partially offset by 30% increase in video and asset infrastructure. Infrastructure accounted for 25% of our total home revenues compared to 18% in 2009. Operating margin in the quarter for Home increased to 9% from 7.1% in the fourth quarter of last year. And for the full year, operating margin also improved 7.5% from 5% in 2009. This improvement was driven by product mix and a reduction in operating cost. 
Moving now to the balance sheet. At separation, we received a $3.2 billion in cash from Motorola. As planned, we expect to receive an additional $300 million once certain cash repatriation activities are completed over time by our former parent company. Approximately 1/3 of our cash outside the United States was primarily used to capitalize and fund the working capital need of our international business. On Page 16 of our slide presentation, you'll see our year-end balance sheet on a GAAP and pro forma basis. In the pro forma view, we've incorporated the cash from Motorola to give you another view as to our balance sheet position as we head into the new year. 
We continue to make good progress in working capital management in both the Mobile Devices and Home businesses. Inventory at year end was down slightly from third quarter, and our days sales inventory improved sequentially to 30 days from 36 days.  Accounts receivable was essentially flat with the third quarter and days sales outstanding declined sequentially to 41 days from 48 days. Our overall SaaS conversion cycle improved sequentially to 10 days, and this compares to 13 days at the end of 2009. 
In the quarter, we generated operating cash flow of $225 million, our sixth consecutive quarter of positive cash flow. For the full year, we generated $606 million in operating cash flows. This compares to an outflow in 2009 of over $1.1 billion. Finally, in recent weeks, we completed a $500 million 3-year unsecured credit facility, 10 leading banks committed to this facility with favorable terms and conditions. 
Turning now to our outlook for the first quarter. As we indicated last December, given seasonality in the United States and improved competitive conditions in the U.S. smartphone market, we expect operating earnings for Motorola Mobility to be in the range around breakeven. In Mobile Devices, we expect significant growth in smartphones and total revenue compared to first quarter of 2010. We also expect an operating loss significantly below the year-ago quarter. 
In Home, compared to the first quarter of 2010, we expect slightly higher revenues and higher operating margin. A per share basis for Motorola Mobility, we expect to incur a net loss in the range of $26 million to $62 million, equivalent to a loss of $0.09 to $0.21 per share. This loss includes a provision for income taxes of approximately $25 million, which I will explain in more detail in a moment. 
Now I would like to provide the following color for full year 2011. In mobile devices, we expect revenue growth this year to be driven by the shipment of 20 million to 23 million smartphones and tablet devices combined. In our Home business, we expect revenues in 2011 to be comparable to 2010. For the company, research and development and general and administrative costs spend will be very tightly manage. Sales and marketing will increase in mobile devices to support new product introduction and grow our top line. We expect total stock compensation and intangible amortization expenses to approximate $55 million per quarter comparable with 2010. 
From an operating profit perspective for the full year, we expect low-single-digit operating margin in mobile devices, a significant improvement compared to the operating loss last year. In Home, we expect slight operating margin improvement for 2011 compared to 2010. Below operating income, we expect approximately $10 million in net expenses each quarter. This includes cost associated with foreign currency management and exchange rate fluctuation, partially offset by modest interest income and our cash and cash equivalents. 
With respect to income taxes, we anticipate an ongoing annual effective tax rate for the full year of approximately 30%. Given our expected geographic distribution of operating profits and losses in 2011, we expect some volatility in the quarterly tax rate as compared to our projected annual rate. This is due to tax expense on foreign earned income, which for now, cannot be offset by tax benefits on U.S. operating results. As a result, we plan to provide you with an estimate of our expected income tax provision for the upcoming quarter on each of our earnings calls. 
In the first quarter, we expect a tax provision of approximately $25 million, as I just mentioned. Over time, as we achieve normalized earning levels across our various geographies and we are able to utilize our deferred tax asset, we expect a lower annual tax rate. Finally, with regards to share counts, as of January 4, we had 294 million basic shares outstanding and approximately 305 million shares on a fully diluted basis. Through the balance of the year, we anticipate only a modest increase in share count. 
The segment and consolidated earnings guidance we have provided today is on a non-GAAP basis where applicable and excludes stock-based compensation expense intangible asset amortization and items similar to those historically highlighted in our quarterly earnings result. 
With that, I will turn the call back over to Dean to start the Q&A.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And it looks like our first question will come from the side of the Mark Sue with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And it looks like our first question will come from the side of the Mark Sue with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sanjay, perhaps if you can give us some more details on the weakness that you saw in the midrange smartphone and if we should extrapolate anything into the high end? And then more importantly, as we look at the promotional dollars associated with each new
componenttext: Sanjay, perhaps if you can give us some more details on the weakness that you saw in the midrange smartphone and if we should extrapolate anything into the high end? And then more importantly, as we look at the promotional dollars associated with each new smartphone, do you think AT&T and other expanding customers for Motorola are willing to spend similar levels of advertising spending that Verizon did in the past with the original DROID, as they transition to a new device? And if not, will it take Motorola to make up that incremental advertising spending?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, with respect to midrange smartphones, the weakness that you saw was largely in United States. At T-Mobile, as you know, at Verizon, as well as AT&T, we have midrange smartphones and we had anticipated, as a result of availability of tiered data pric
componenttext: Mark, with respect to midrange smartphones, the weakness that you saw was largely in United States. At T-Mobile, as you know, at Verizon, as well as AT&T, we have midrange smartphones and we had anticipated, as a result of availability of tiered data pricing, that there will be accelerated take-up of mid-tier phones. Actually, what we continue to see was that, that was not the case and that consumers continue to buy high-tiered smartphones like DROID X. And I think that was actually the fact that I referred to in my script. With respect to the second part of your question about marketing dollars, I anticipate that there will be -- there's actually quite a lot of excitement around ATRIX 4G, as you saw at CES and we are certainly looking to support our products, but we are also looking to leverage the pull from our carriers without being specific about the support. As you know, we have a  very good continuing relationship with Verizon and I think they continue to view the DROID franchise as being a very important franchise for them. So we will certainly continue to participate and work closely with Verizon, but we will diversify our portfolio in the United States with AT&T and others. And I have no reason for believing that there is not going to be support. The levels,  I think, I probably can't comment with precision at the moment. But certainly, I think, given the quality of our portfolio, we are looking to support our portfolio in the marketplace.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the side of Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the side of Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sanjay and team, congratulations on the separation and your independence. I wanted to dig in into the guidance of the year of the units 20 million to 23 million. Definitely surprised me, a good number. Sanjay, can you give us a little bit more color on mi
componenttext: Sanjay and team, congratulations on the separation and your independence. I wanted to dig in into the guidance of the year of the units 20 million to 23 million. Definitely surprised me, a good number. Sanjay, can you give us a little bit more color on mix between smartphones and tablets? And also, since the iPhone was announced at Verizon, it's still not in the marketplace, but can you tell us any color on how demand has changed at Verizon for you since the announcement was made? And how should we think about that again going here into the first quarter?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: There are 2 portions to that question, Ittai, if I could take the second first. Certainly, since the announcement of iPhone, we have seen a little slowdown in our of our sell-through of our devices because there's clearly an anticipation of some devices c
componenttext: There are 2 portions to that question, Ittai, if I could take the second first. Certainly, since the announcement of iPhone, we have seen a little slowdown in our of our sell-through of our devices because there's clearly an anticipation of some devices coming through Verizon, so we have seen that affect even prior to the iPhone launching. But I think we continue to feel that when the door swings occur, consumers coming to Verizon stores, that being offered the choices that they're being offered by Verizon, because the fundamental principle that Verizon has stuck to is that they want to offer choices to their consumers. As the consumers come into the store, they will see a choice. And I think time will tell as to what percentage of those doors swings actually translates to which brand purchase. But I think that we have seen some slowdown as a result of the announcement from Verizon. With respect to color around 20 million to 23 million units this year, clearly, vast majority of that will be smartphones. In the United States, our focus will continue to be at the high end. But I anticipate that the mid-tier market in Latin America and China will become more important for us and there will be continued growth there. I think in Europe, which also is a little more of a mid-tier marketplace, we have seen good traction with DEFY and we'll continue to introduce products to support that further. I would say one other thing. And as you know, we've had a team in China, which has been very focused on what we call MMCP, mass market consumer products, or voice-centric feature phones. And they contributed in 2010 in stabilizing our feature phone shipment in second half. As we go through 2011, we will shift focus for that team towards low- and mid-tier smartphones. So I anticipate that they will be able to support some volume shipments for us in Latin America and China and Europe, where mid-tier is much more important part of the marketplace. For tablets, I think, clearly, we have a very compelling product. As you know, there was a lot of excitement around that product and we will launch that product at Verizon in February. And with Honeycomb and some of the new innovative services that you will see there, we're excited about that product. But it is really, at the moment, a little too early to be precise about how much volume that may lead to us, either in the first quarter or through the year. I would say that in second half of the year, you will see us introduce tablets, 7-inch, and various other form factor. And we anticipate that, that will further support our growth into tablets that converge to computing devices.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the side of Brian Modoff with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the side of Brian Modoff with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kind of calling on Ittai's question, how do you see Q1 smartphone volume kind of progressing with the iPhone at Verizon? Do you see volumes down? What kind of color can you give us? And then can you discuss your diversification progress away from Verizon?
componenttext: Kind of calling on Ittai's question, how do you see Q1 smartphone volume kind of progressing with the iPhone at Verizon? Do you see volumes down? What kind of color can you give us? And then can you discuss your diversification progress away from Verizon? How do you think you're going to do in some of the other U.S. carriers through the year and particularly in the current quarter? And then also, can you talk about your efforts internationally, particularly in China and Latin America? And then possibly if you could comment on Europe, that would be great.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, as I said to Ittai, we have already seen some slowdown of our shipment at Verizon as a result of some anticipation picking up for other devices. So that has occurred. But we have a meaningful relationship with Verizon and that relationship continue
componenttext: Brian, as I said to Ittai, we have already seen some slowdown of our shipment at Verizon as a result of some anticipation picking up for other devices. So that has occurred. But we have a meaningful relationship with Verizon and that relationship continues in a strong way. And I'm not yet convinced that Verizon will not continue to push forward with DROID as a franchise. And of course, we participate in that, others participate also, and we have a good relationship with Verizon and continued good relationship with Verizon there. In terms of diversification in U.S., you have seen the launch or at least the announcement of ATRIX 4G at AT&T, you will see us diversify in retail channel as well, as with the other carriers in the U.S. So I think if you look at our international diversification, even the fourth quarter results shows the growth in our shipments of smartphones in China and Latin America, and to a certain extent, in Europe. And I think that in 2011, I think we will have a much greater focus in diversification and growth in our shipments in these regions. So already, I think you've seen that. And then of course, with the introduction of tablet, that creates another growth area for us. And then we're actually excited about that possibility. Outside of U.S., you will see us launch WiFi tablets as well as 3G tablets in other regions also. So that creates further opportunity for us in 2011 also.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you see tablets, Sanjay -- last question, do you see tablets kind of midrange tablet, as well as lower end kind of fall on in theme you have on the smartphone side making more affordable tablet-type products for the emerging markets?
componenttext: And do you see tablets, Sanjay -- last question, do you see tablets kind of midrange tablet, as well as lower end kind of fall on in theme you have on the smartphone side making more affordable tablet-type products for the emerging markets?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have done a fair bit of consumer research, Brian, and we definitely see segmentation in the marketplace. The tablets that resonate with teenagers and kids and women is different than the tablets that resonates with professionals who want to do enterpri
componenttext: We have done a fair bit of consumer research, Brian, and we definitely see segmentation in the marketplace. The tablets that resonate with teenagers and kids and women is different than the tablets that resonates with professionals who want to do enterprise services and want to run Citrix and other capabilities on the tablet. So we definitely see good reason to introduce multiple different display size and price points into the marketplace. And of course, as a result of our participation in the whole marketplace, we see growing opportunity, actually, in combination with TV sets, where people use these tablets in conjunction with their TV viewing experience. So we definitely see growth opportunities for multiple different price points in tablets.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then we'll move next to that side of Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: And then we'll move next to that side of Edward Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're moving to a lot of different product areas, diversifying across carriers. You've got tablets, you have midrange phones, smartphones and all. It seems that given the competition especially a number of the bigger guys talking about going into lower m
componenttext: You're moving to a lot of different product areas, diversifying across carriers. You've got tablets, you have midrange phones, smartphones and all. It seems that given the competition especially a number of the bigger guys talking about going into lower market or mass market smartphones, doesn't this increase your reliance on, say, Google? You haven't done, announced much in the Windows side of it, I know that there was always a plan to have both OSs, but it seems mostly devoted to Android. Are you worried about your exposure to Google's kind of varying approach to the OS, given your dependence on it for most of your products at this point?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, we have a great partnership with Google. As you know, we're the first ones to launch Honeycomb, Android 3.0. And together in working with Google, I think we will deliver an experience, which will definitely be seen to be extremely competitive with oth
componenttext: Ed, we have a great partnership with Google. As you know, we're the first ones to launch Honeycomb, Android 3.0. And together in working with Google, I think we will deliver an experience, which will definitely be seen to be extremely competitive with other products in the marketplace. So I think that, that partnership is a very important partnership for us. Having said that, in mid-tier, most of the devices are not Google-experienced devices. Most the devices follow at the trailing edge and their -- our ability to use our own software capability, we use BLUR, we use enterprise capability, we use multimedia anywhere and use phone diagnostics and device diagnostics, I think, actually, enables us to differentiate. In mid-tier, brand, channel distribution, become even more important. So I actually -- of course, we use Android operating environment and we have a great partnership with Google and there is that dependence. But in mid-tier, actually, I think the factors that enables success are more varied. In leading edge, you have to be one of the first of very fast follower at the latest release of software. In mid-tier, the dynamic is slightly different. So as the expansion occurs to mid-tier, I think it's both good for Google because they obviously get more broader base of consumers looking for such results. It's also good for us because I think we can differentiate ourselves there as well.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: That begs the question, of course, that when AT&T cut pricing on iPhone in response to Verizon getting it tiered, it's putting an enormous pressure into some of your subsidy, but on everybody else who is trying to compete with these. As you know, Nokia su
componenttext: That begs the question, of course, that when AT&T cut pricing on iPhone in response to Verizon getting it tiered, it's putting an enormous pressure into some of your subsidy, but on everybody else who is trying to compete with these. As you know, Nokia suspended Sushi to AT&T because they couldn't -- they didn't even get any traction against the iPhone at that pricing. Are you feeling that in the smartphone side of it? And is this pushing you to maybe do some more mid-tier, low-end stuff where you don't have the subsidy pressure that you might have in the high end of it? Or is this just natural diversification to try to balance out to the ups and downs of the smartphone business, which seems to get a lot more rocky given everybody's plan for price releases this year?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the dynamics are different in the U.S. than they are in Latin America and China. In U.S., as I think you likely pointed out, a lot of the high-tier phones, over a period of time, come to the middle tier. And you will see some of our products follo
componenttext: I think the dynamics are different in the U.S. than they are in Latin America and China. In U.S., as I think you likely pointed out, a lot of the high-tier phones, over a period of time, come to the middle tier. And you will see some of our products following that trend as well. With Latin America and China, there are much more dedicated devices that are being delivered to meet the requirements of mid-tier. And so the particular effect that you cite is different in U.S. than it is elsewhere. I actually think that 2011, while the mid-tier market will begin to develop in U.S., it still continues to be very much a high-tier marketplace. And in all of these things, I think with some of the innovation that we're delivering and common platform, and leverage of platform and leverage of our software, and our brand and distribution in Latin America and China, I think we are well positioned.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to the side of Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll move next to the side of Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just got a couple of them. One would be on the NOLs, on the tax rate. You guys are talking about a 30% tax rate going forward. I just wondered whether -- I think if I'm right, most of the NOLs are in the U.S. So I'm wondering whether the -- is that tellin
componenttext: Just got a couple of them. One would be on the NOLs, on the tax rate. You guys are talking about a 30% tax rate going forward. I just wondered whether -- I think if I'm right, most of the NOLs are in the U.S. So I'm wondering whether the -- is that telling us something about whether -- will you expect profits to come from, first, regionally, or you expect the international profits to come through, mainly, initially and then U.S. profits later? I'm just trying to understand whether we can make any further color on that from you related to that tax comment.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Marc, Rod, I'd be glad to do that. Let me give some color on the comments I made earlier and I'll try to be bit broader here to create a better understanding. But today, of course, we operate in multiple jurisdictions, U.S. and foreign entities, a
componenttext: This is Marc, Rod, I'd be glad to do that. Let me give some color on the comments I made earlier and I'll try to be bit broader here to create a better understanding. But today, of course, we operate in multiple jurisdictions, U.S. and foreign entities, and there's variety of tax rules. In the foreign operations, we're generating profits in many of our subsidiaries because of our manufacturing operations and our distribution centers. In the U.S., we're not going to be able to take the benefit on the operating losses that we may be incurring early in the year. So in fact, that because of the operating losses that we've had historically, it's created these NOLs that we're carrying forward and some other attributes with the separation. So overall, when the financial profile of Mobility improves, we'll be able to take advantage of those NOLs. But today, a lot of the profits of the company are going to be offshore. But again, as the earnings improve overall, we'll be able to benefit from the fact that we have significant tax NOLs inside the U.S. operations. So what we'll do is, for the full year, I was prepared to give guidance today that we expect the number to be approximately 30% for the full year and I'll be able to give quarterly guidance in terms of our expectation of the exact number, and today it's $25 million. I would expect that number to grow quarterly as the business increases.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then if I could just -- if I could follow-up, Sanjay, I just had a question for you on the XOOM and the way that you guys -- I mean, it looks like a great product, you guys were showing it, though, without a working operating system and that has initi
componenttext: And then if I could just -- if I could follow-up, Sanjay, I just had a question for you on the XOOM and the way that you guys -- I mean, it looks like a great product, you guys were showing it, though, without a working operating system and that has initiated a whole bunch of speculation out in the market and whether Honeycomb is really ready to go yet and why you would do that as opposed to showing it with a working system. So I wondered if you could just, maybe put an end to some of the speculation and give us the reasons why you made that decision and maybe a little background on that?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me just start by saying that our anticipation launch of XOOM continues to be in February. I think it is possible that there'll be a very modest variation from that, but our anticipation is that we will launch fully functional commercial 3G XOOM with V
componenttext: Let me just start by saying that our anticipation launch of XOOM continues to be in February. I think it is possible that there'll be a very modest variation from that, but our anticipation is that we will launch fully functional commercial 3G XOOM with Verizon in February. And of course, Rod, you would remember that, that was the commitment that we made when we launched it at CES with Verizon. So there's no change to that. I actually think that the positive reason is that, I think, this operating system -- and I have been, as you know, involved in Android pretty much from the beginning. I think this 3.0 is probably as innovative, if not, more innovative than what the 2.0 delivered in Android ecosystem. And you will recall that 2.0 became the vehicle on which drove the growth for Android. So I think that the amount of work, the number of innovative things that are going on here are quite large and, therefore, we, of course, demoed only a small number of things when we demoed it at CES. I'm pretty confident that you will see some very good applications and services, but I should also say that in working with Google, we will continue to add new services to this device through the course of it. And of course, all of these XOOM 3G tablets are upgradable to 4G. The Verizon 3G tablets are upgradable to 4G LTE. So anyone who acquires these in February or March will be able to upgrade it to 4G. So I think that -- it's really a software as well as hardware, which is very upgradable, because of the memory and hardware capability that we have built in. This product will have a long life. But we're pretty confident that we can launch it on the kind of schedules that I mentioned to you.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to the side of Simona Jankowski with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll move next to the side of Simona Jankowski with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just had a question first on Mobility and then on Home. On the Mobility side, just curious, Sanjay, what your guidance for 20 million to 22 million units this year assumes directionally for your unit shipment in Verizon? If you think they will be up or
componenttext: I just had a question first on Mobility and then on Home. On the Mobility side, just curious, Sanjay, what your guidance for 20 million to 22 million units this year assumes directionally for your unit shipment in Verizon? If you think they will be up or down this year versus what you ship to them in terms of units last year? And then also I was curious if the results in the fourth quarter were affected by a lower sell-in to Verizon? So I didn't hear your comments that sell-through might have been a bit affected, but curious if Verizon also took down some inventory just in anticipation of the Q1 impact?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Simona, I think, our guidance for smartphone and tablets is 20 million to 23 million units, I think -- I just wanted to be clear, I think you said, if I didn't mishear you, I think you said 20 to 22 million units. The second thing was that I think the bes
componenttext: Simona, I think, our guidance for smartphone and tablets is 20 million to 23 million units, I think -- I just wanted to be clear, I think you said, if I didn't mishear you, I think you said 20 to 22 million units. The second thing was that I think the best way to say it, Simona, is that we anticipate that for our devices, that inventory in the channels are at quite normal levels. So by extension, obviously, the sell-ins also was reduced. But I'm not commenting particularly on Verizon, but generally, broadly for our mid-tier products, the sell-in was also reduced. And of course, you saw that we guided you to higher end of '14 and with 13 7, we delivered -- they closed to the high end of that number. So by the way, our sense is from third quarter to fourth quarter, the growth in smartphone shipment was marginally outstripped by our growth in smartphones shipment. So very modestly, I think, we gained in market share in fourth quarter.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Sanjay, just the question was on that 20 million to 23 million units number for this year, does that assume that your units to Verizon this year in 2011 will be up or down versus what you ship to them last year?
componenttext: And Sanjay, just the question was on that 20 million to 23 million units number for this year, does that assume that your units to Verizon this year in 2011 will be up or down versus what you ship to them last year?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think I can give you that position this early in the year. We clearly have a view, but there's a large number of factors, which will impact that, and, Simona, I'm not comfortable giving you a number, not because I'm trying to hide, I don't -- the
componenttext: I don't think I can give you that position this early in the year. We clearly have a view, but there's a large number of factors, which will impact that, and, Simona, I'm not comfortable giving you a number, not because I'm trying to hide, I don't -- the range is [indiscernible] fitted, it's probably not meaningful.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just quickly on my home question, was just basically -- I was just curious on your kind of long-term optimism for that business of mid-single-digit growth considering the decline last year and just flat expectations for this year.
componenttext: And just quickly on my home question, was just basically -- I was just curious on your kind of long-term optimism for that business of mid-single-digit growth considering the decline last year and just flat expectations for this year.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Simona, this is Dan Moloney. I will just say that we continue to see the economy here in the U.S. improving slowly. When you look at how much housing has been impacted over the last 24 months, it has resulted in several of our operator customers, bringing
componenttext: Simona, this is Dan Moloney. I will just say that we continue to see the economy here in the U.S. improving slowly. When you look at how much housing has been impacted over the last 24 months, it has resulted in several of our operator customers, bringing inventory back out of the field and that is going to take time for that to work through the system. So our optimism is about the market, continuing to expand its capability and new innovative capabilities around high-definition, 3D, MPEG4, other things that will drive technology upgrades. But 2011, will again have some of the same headwind constraints we saw over the last 12 months that we believe will keep the market relatively flat.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the side of Richard Kramer with Arete.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the side of Richard Kramer with Arete.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, I'd like to ask Marc. Can you talk through how you might look to reduce OpEx overall in 2011? I know you give us guidance for flattish R&D and SG&A and Verizon and delta marketing, but can we expect any restructuring to take place, or any major loo
componenttext: First, I'd like to ask Marc. Can you talk through how you might look to reduce OpEx overall in 2011? I know you give us guidance for flattish R&D and SG&A and Verizon and delta marketing, but can we expect any restructuring to take place, or any major look, now that you're a fully independent company at the cost structure? Sanjay, could you comment a little bit about all the acquisitions you've made, Azingo, 280 North, Vector and whatnot. Do you think that Motorola needs to have its own software platform at some point in the future? Or have you bought these assets to improve the differentiation on Android and the legacy future play platform. And maybe a quick one for Dan. We've been waiting for many years for Motorola to make a bigger push to internationalize the sales of Home. Is that something that you think, given the flat U.S. market that you might try to do in 2011, or is that still -- should we still expect a similar mix, which is really predominantly in 4, 4/5 or so U.S.?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, [indiscernible]. Thanks, Richard. This is Marc, let me take the first part of the question on cost structure. We did -- we've done a lot of the heavy lifting relative to operating expenses over the last 2 years. We've taken the cost down by $1.5 b
componenttext: Thanks, [indiscernible]. Thanks, Richard. This is Marc, let me take the first part of the question on cost structure. We did -- we've done a lot of the heavy lifting relative to operating expenses over the last 2 years. We've taken the cost down by $1.5 billion. Our expectation is that the cost structure, research and development and other cost to operate the business are at a level that we can now leverage. We'll reinvest in certain areas, software in particular, on R&D, but our expectation is that we will be able to maintain that same kind of cost structure year on year. So don't expect much in terms of restructuring. And selling and marketing cost, both the distribution side as well as advertising and promotion, we will ramp that accordingly with the growth particularly in the Mobile Device business. So if I look with you year-on-year, 2010 to 2011, across those categories, you'll see selling and marketing increase accordingly as the business ramps.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Richard, with respect to your question on software, acquisitions and platform, we have clearly made some acquisitions, they've all been small acquisitions. And we're focused in acquiring either particular technology, which helps us in the marketplace or t
componenttext: Richard, with respect to your question on software, acquisitions and platform, we have clearly made some acquisitions, they've all been small acquisitions. And we're focused in acquiring either particular technology, which helps us in the marketplace or talent and I think we've done a good job of being able to attract very good teams to Motorola. In terms of platform -- and these teams, by the way, help us with differentiation in the ways that I talked about. In enterprise, in delivering, push the Internet multiple service, in device diagnostics, in media anywhere, Vector particularly, and I think with respect to platform, what I've said, Richard, a number of times before is that I believe owning a platform is a good thing to do if you can get as applications and services to be competitive and if you have the ability to invest in such a way that you keep that platform at the leading edge. I do not believe that the current technology node, that is an opportunity for us to introduce a new platform. If there is a disruptive new technology transition, I think that may be a place where, if we have financial wherewithal and skill, I think we will consider -- reconsider that. But at this point, we are committed to Android through 2011 and we continue to move forward full force.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Richard, in terms of the question on the home. I think you are correct. If you look at the last couple of years, we've had a relatively stable percentage of business inside the U.S. versus outside. I continue to believe that as the video business model ev
componenttext: Richard, in terms of the question on the home. I think you are correct. If you look at the last couple of years, we've had a relatively stable percentage of business inside the U.S. versus outside. I continue to believe that as the video business model evolves outside North America, we will continue to see new opportunities we can chase. Certainly, there has been some consolidation in Latin America of the traditional cable properties, which has created some new opportunities. China remains a very fragmented market around video distribution and as that begins to sort itself through, it should create some new opportunities. And Western Europe has had spotty opportunities over the last few years that we believe as the general economy in Western Europe improves in many countries will create new opportunities. So long term, I'm still optimistic that we can drive incremental business outside the U.S.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the side of Jim Suva with Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the side of Jim Suva with Citi.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we look ahead, I think it becomes pretty critical to address the diversification globally with Motorola. Could you focus on my question about Europe and Motorola plans, or do have plans to go into Europe as Samsung, LG and HTC are currently going after
componenttext: As we look ahead, I think it becomes pretty critical to address the diversification globally with Motorola. Could you focus on my question about Europe and Motorola plans, or do have plans to go into Europe as Samsung, LG and HTC are currently going after Europe pretty aggressively with their Android efforts? And one has to wonder if Motorola has plans to do so, the timeline and cost of doing so.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jim, very precisely at the moment, our plan for Europe is to continue with the strategy that we had in 2010. In fourth quarter, we launched multiple devices with multiple carriers in 3 -- 4 countries, in Germany, France, Italy and U.K. And actually, very
componenttext: Jim, very precisely at the moment, our plan for Europe is to continue with the strategy that we had in 2010. In fourth quarter, we launched multiple devices with multiple carriers in 3 -- 4 countries, in Germany, France, Italy and U.K. And actually, very modestly, in Spain as well. And our plan is to continue to get traction with our portfolio in these countries. I think we're getting pretty good traction with the tablet as well, with our XOOM tablet. We will continue with that. We do not, as of right now, have a plan for a very large marketing investment. I have -- as I've discussed this on this call -- on our earnings call before, I do not anticipate that in first half 2011 that we would do anything significant. In second half, there may be opportunities. And what I would look for is a relationship with the carriers where we can leverage our investment dollars and get their support. If I had that opportunity or for that matter in retail channel, if I had that opportunity, I will reevaluate second half 2011. But for first half, I do not anticipate making a big investment. And as you rightly point out, others are investing that money. That's, of course, puts us at a competitive disadvantage when we do go there. But given our financial situation, we believe that leveraging our dollars in the U.S., China and Latin America is a better way to go.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And it looks like our next question will come from the side of Mark McKechnie with Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: And it looks like our next question will come from the side of Mark McKechnie with Gleacher & Company.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Simple question, maybe for Marc. Any kind of detail you can give us on the gross margins for your handsets, for your -- where you are relative to your target? Where you think those can go for both the Androids? And then also, just a better sense of -- it
componenttext: Simple question, maybe for Marc. Any kind of detail you can give us on the gross margins for your handsets, for your -- where you are relative to your target? Where you think those can go for both the Androids? And then also, just a better sense of -- it looked like you saw a little bit of strength in that feature phone business, maybe you could talk about how you see that going forward, Sanjay.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. So with respect to gross margins overall for Motorola Mobility, it was 27%. What we said historically is that the Home business as a percentage of -- as compared to the total gross margin for mobility is slightly higher in the mobile device
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. So with respect to gross margins overall for Motorola Mobility, it was 27%. What we said historically is that the Home business as a percentage of -- as compared to the total gross margin for mobility is slightly higher in the mobile device business below that obviously as the growth in mobile devices moves up, I guess less linear than home the gross margin will be impacted. Having said that, as a result of getting into both tablet space and the continued growth in smartphone business into 2011, we expect to perform well on the gross margin side. I won't give specific numbers with respect to gross margin, what I commented on was more of a growth story relative to units and operating margin -- operating margin targets.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, on feature phones, as you know I have -- as I said a little earlier, we have a team in China, which works with our OEM partners to develop at almost under a separate roof, with a different cost structure, with different overhead, what we call MMCP,
componenttext: Mark, on feature phones, as you know I have -- as I said a little earlier, we have a team in China, which works with our OEM partners to develop at almost under a separate roof, with a different cost structure, with different overhead, what we call MMCP, the mass market consumer product, and they have driven very significant growth in the success that we've had with our feature phone units as compared to the decline that it was seeing before. As we look forward to 2011, in second half this year, we will refocus that team to what we call MMSP, mass market smartphones, and that team will then go drive our presence in low and mid-tier smartphone marketplace because with the deployment of 3G around the world, particularly Latin America and China, we see the market for lower tier smartphone becoming much more important. And I actually believe that there is possibility that, that transition could be gross market margin accretive for us. Of course, that has to be seen yet because that is a transition that will occur as we go to 2011.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to the side of Jeff Kvaal with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And we'll move next to the side of Jeff Kvaal with Barclays Capital.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if the 3 of you could help us understand a little bit more the dynamics involved in ASPs in the mobile business. Obviously, a mix shift towards the mid-tier would hurt, but on the other hand ones including tablets in there. Any sense of ho
componenttext: I was wondering if the 3 of you could help us understand a little bit more the dynamics involved in ASPs in the mobile business. Obviously, a mix shift towards the mid-tier would hurt, but on the other hand ones including tablets in there. Any sense of how we should sort through that would be helpful.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start, Jeff, on ASPs. With respect to -- in general, on the focus on the guidance relative to the 20 million to 23 million smartphones and tablets, which obviously is significant growth off of the 13.7 million. So the dynamic is going to be that the
componenttext: I'll start, Jeff, on ASPs. With respect to -- in general, on the focus on the guidance relative to the 20 million to 23 million smartphones and tablets, which obviously is significant growth off of the 13.7 million. So the dynamic is going to be that the tablets will clearly have a higher ASP profile and will continue to improve our volume relative to the performance category, the higher tier. However, as we just pointed out, Latin America and China marketplace, particularly in the midrange for smartphones, will be very important market for us and we expect significant growth in that year-on-year. So that will have some impact as well on ASPs. I'm not going to, at this point, be able to get too specific relative to ASPs, Jeff, but clearly, clearly, the volume is going to the mix associated with those 3 categories are going to have an impact on the average selling prices.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Care to speculate, up or down, Marc?
componenttext: Okay. Care to speculate, up or down, Marc?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you'll have to let us report on that, Jeff.
componenttext: I think you'll have to let us report on that, Jeff.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, Sanjay, for you. I wanted to ask how you're feeling about the tablet ecosystem, what the business models are going to be in play there with subsidies, et cetera, et cetera? I think previously you commented on what your early impressions
componenttext: And then I guess, Sanjay, for you. I wanted to ask how you're feeling about the tablet ecosystem, what the business models are going to be in play there with subsidies, et cetera, et cetera? I think previously you commented on what your early impressions of the margin structures would be in tablets as well?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if I could just reiterate what I said, Jeff. My anticipation is that the margins and tablet business, by and large, would be lower than the performance tier or higher tier of smartphone marketplace. And of course, remember that even the table
componenttext: Yes, I think if I could just reiterate what I said, Jeff. My anticipation is that the margins and tablet business, by and large, would be lower than the performance tier or higher tier of smartphone marketplace. And of course, remember that even the tablet business will get segmented into 2 kind of broad categories. One is whether it's 3G or 4G or not, and the second would be of course whether it's Wi-Fi. That's the best one segmentation. I'm sorry, let me start again. I kind of got myself confused. One is whether it's 3G, 4G versus Wi-Fi and second is whether it's 7, 8, 10 or 11-inch. This size will make a difference. So let me just, by way of illustration, say, that a 7-inch Wi-Fi tablet obviously will carry much smaller gross margin than a 10-inch 4G tablet will. So that's 1 factor. But by and large, I would say that the tablet business, because meaningful portion of it will go through retail, would be lower gross margin business. I would say there is uncertainty in my mind as to how carriers will deal with tablets. I think, again, I think if I have to say clearly as they get 2-year subscription, there is much greater willingness to subscribe. But it's not clear what portion of tablet sales will go through -- will have to wear subscription. So far, what we've seen is around 50% of the tablets tend to be Wi-Fi tablets. So there's uncertainty as to, on average, what level of subsidy will be available on tablets. So i don't know if I -- sorry to confuse, but those are the factors that will be in play. I think that China will also be quite important there.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the side of Ehud Gelblum with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the side of Ehud Gelblum with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Eddie. So a couple of questions. First of all, Sanjay, you had said that since the announcement of the iPhone, you'd seen some slow down in orders. How do you know that it's not just regular seasonality in Q1? So that's first question. Second, In
componenttext: This is Eddie. So a couple of questions. First of all, Sanjay, you had said that since the announcement of the iPhone, you'd seen some slow down in orders. How do you know that it's not just regular seasonality in Q1? So that's first question. Second, In look at your international opportunity, can you give us a sense as to, either percentage-wise or whatever you can do, to break out China, Latin America and Europe in Q4. And when you're looking at your guidance for 20 million to 23 million, can you give us some sense as to how China, Latin America and Europe kind of look in that guidance? And then trying to tackle a question from a different angle, if you had -- clearly, if you look at the percentage of your phones that were Android smartphones this quarter, it was lower than the percent last quarter. Your feature phones did better, growth wise. Your ASP was down $10, you said midrange was weak. What would -- what was the -- I'm imagining that your Android smartphone ASP, if you looked just at that, was actually up. Can you give us a sense as to what the growth rate in the Android-only ASP was so we can kind of separate that effect out, so we can see the effect of less midrange versus the effect of the mix between smarts and features?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I will defer some of this to Marc, but I'll take the first part of your question as to why we caught -- my comment around -- and not so much a slowdown in sell-in, but I think the sell-through is what I was commenting on. I would say, when I look at varia
componenttext: I will defer some of this to Marc, but I'll take the first part of your question as to why we caught -- my comment around -- and not so much a slowdown in sell-in, but I think the sell-through is what I was commenting on. I would say, when I look at variation from what we had before, I think when I look at the change, the change was greater than would be accounted for by seasonality alone. But it's probably the reason that I made that comment. Marc, I will refer -- defer the guidance questions to you, as well as the ASP questions.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me give you a little bit more color relative to geographic mix and give you some insights into 2011. So in the fourth quarter, 63% of the revenues of mobile devices were in the U.S., by the way that mix, so we improved internationally, it was a g
componenttext: Yes, let me give you a little bit more color relative to geographic mix and give you some insights into 2011. So in the fourth quarter, 63% of the revenues of mobile devices were in the U.S., by the way that mix, so we improved internationally, it was a greater part of our mix in Q4, it was 68% in Q3. The other thing that wanted to comment on was the smartphone mix overall. So in Q3, about 25% of our total smartphones were in markets outside the U.S. as we shifted into Q4 as it's more like 1/3 of our volumes. As we go into 2011, clearly, of course, our core prioritization strategy is to expand internationally. That's not to say that the U.S. overall numbers won't grow, they will. But the operations and regions outside the U.S. will contribute more as a percentage we expect to the total. I didn't understand -- you wouldn't mind just asking the question again related to the ASP on the Android devices and I'll see if I can give any color on it.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. The simple question is that your total ASP went from 224 in Q3 to 214. What did -- if we looked at just the Android ASPs, ignoring the feature phones, the 3.8 million Androids to the 4.9 million Android, what is the ASP there?
componenttext: Sure. The simple question is that your total ASP went from 224 in Q3 to 214. What did -- if we looked at just the Android ASPs, ignoring the feature phones, the 3.8 million Androids to the 4.9 million Android, what is the ASP there?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it really comes down to the product mix that we spoke to the midrange devices were clearly the over all and within the Android -- within Android category, we're impacting the overall ASPs. I mean, really that's just a question, which you may not h
componenttext: I think it really comes down to the product mix that we spoke to the midrange devices were clearly the over all and within the Android -- within Android category, we're impacting the overall ASPs. I mean, really that's just a question, which you may not have been too satisfied with...

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: But Marc, were the ASPs and Android up 10%? Are they up 20%? I mean, is there some sense we can get as to...
componenttext: But Marc, were the ASPs and Android up 10%? Are they up 20%? I mean, is there some sense we can get as to...

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I can give you overall numbers. As you saw, we reported that the overall was 214 and Android obviously being  4.9 million of the 11.3 has an impact on it. So we [indiscernible] not to break out the total right now. But really, going forward, mix is go
componenttext: No. I can give you overall numbers. As you saw, we reported that the overall was 214 and Android obviously being  4.9 million of the 11.3 has an impact on it. So we [indiscernible] not to break out the total right now. But really, going forward, mix is going to play a huge -- have a huge impact on the ongoing ASPs. We're going to continue to be on the leading edge of our devices and we think we'll get appropriate price for that, but it really depends upon how much of our mix is going to be on the higher end on the tablet side and on...

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: What I'm just kind of going for is from your commentary, it makes it sound as though smartphone ASP was up because you sought more high-end smartphones than midrange. What I want to make sure is that smartphone ASP in fact was up and that you didn't have
componenttext: What I'm just kind of going for is from your commentary, it makes it sound as though smartphone ASP was up because you sought more high-end smartphones than midrange. What I want to make sure is that smartphone ASP in fact was up and that you didn't have an effect of perhaps lower end pricing on your -- you may have been selling more high-end, but you may have had a lower price. I just want to make sure that, that didn't happen and so therefore your smartphone ASP was up because of a bit...

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: You shouldn't conclude that. What I want to say is that, again, that the revenues from smartphones are a significant amount of our total revenues today. And clearly, with the ASPs going from $224 to $214, roughly, quarter-on-quarter, the ASPs on our Andro
componenttext: You shouldn't conclude that. What I want to say is that, again, that the revenues from smartphones are a significant amount of our total revenues today. And clearly, with the ASPs going from $224 to $214, roughly, quarter-on-quarter, the ASPs on our Android devices were somewhat tempered in Q4 relative to Q3.

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And last thing, how do we -- how should we be looking at Q1? I know you haven't given guidance for units, and you gave it on it -- versus a year ago basis, which is moderately helpful. But as we take all these different pieces that go into the pie between
componenttext: And last thing, how do we -- how should we be looking at Q1? I know you haven't given guidance for units, and you gave it on it -- versus a year ago basis, which is moderately helpful. But as we take all these different pieces that go into the pie between the iPhone at Verizon, normal seasonality new product introductions coming up, how are we supposed to look at what the unit number should be in Q1? Better than seasonality? Worse than seasonality? What do you consider is seasonality had a -- anything you can do to give us a sense of what units should look like?

headline: Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well I think, Ehud, we said seasonality is about 7%, and of course -- 7% to 10%, I beg your pardon. And of course, I think there will be some impact beyond that as a result of having iPhone at Verizon. I don't know that I could guide you much more precise
componenttext: Well I think, Ehud, we said seasonality is about 7%, and of course -- 7% to 10%, I beg your pardon. And of course, I think there will be some impact beyond that as a result of having iPhone at Verizon. I don't know that I could guide you much more precisely than that, but a combination of those 2 things. I would anticipate would be larger than 7% to 10%, which would be seasonality alone.
